36001.name: Away Team Skirmish
36001.description:
“Abstract skirmish level combat with Star Trek theme. Each figure represents a single man (or alien). Victory: You win if you kill all opposing men.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Each player starts with a team of eight men. Miniatures or counters, which are marked by race and officer type, are used to represent the combatants. Statistics are given for four types of teams: Federation, Klingon, Romulan, and Borg. Each player chooses one type of team at the start of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

36002.name: Aztec Skirmish
36002.description:
“Battle between Aztecs & Conquistadors. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Leader.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters may be used to represent the combatants. The Aztec force consists of a War Leader, two Jaguar Knights, two Eagle Knights, and 19 Warriors. The Conquistador force consists of a Captain, two Cannons, four Horsemen, and eight Soldiers. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36003.name: Barbarella
36003.description:
A card game inspired by the events and characters of the movie Barbarella.

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are six suits in the deck, each with nine cards. The suites are Barbarella, Allies, Foes, Places, Events, and Things. The players score points by playing six-card combos. Scoring is as follows: one point for three pairs, two points for two three-of-a-kinds, three points for a flush, and four points for a straight which includes one card from each of the six suits. The first player to reach ten points wins the game.

36004.name: Battle for Hoth
36004.description:
“Battle between Rebels & Imperial troops on the Icy World of Hoth. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe. Each figure represents a hero, vehicle or unit of troops. Victory: The Rebels win if they destroy all the AT-AT Walkers. The Empire wins if they destroy the Ion Cannon & the Shield Generators.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Rebel force consists of Luke in Speeder (becomes Luke on Foot if hit), Shield Generator, Ion Cannon, five Snow Speeders, two Laser Turrets, and six Rebel Troop Units. The Empire force consists of four AT-AT Walkers, two AT-AT Scouts, two Probe Droids, two Heavy Blaster Teams, and six Snow Troopers. Each unit is rated for movement distance and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move or attack.

36005.name: Battle for Naboo
36005.description:
“Battle between the Gungan & Federation Armies on Naboo. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe (Episode I). Each figure represents a Leader, Vehicle, or Unit of Troops. Victory: If the Shield Generator Beast is destroyed, the Robots win. The game ends automatically after you go through the deck twice when young Anakin destroys the Federation Carrier Ship, which shuts down all the Robots. The Gungan player wins at this time.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. The Gungan Units include Jar Jar Binks, Gungan Generals, Shieldmen, Slingers, Cavalry, Catapults, and a Shield Beast. The Federation Units include Hover Tanks, Battle Droids, and Droidekas. Each unit is rated for hit points, movement distance, and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common custom deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36006.name: Battlestar Galactica
36006.description:
A two player boardgame based on the original Battlestar Galactica series, with one player as the Cylons and the other as the Battlestar Galactica.

The game is played on a single row of 100 squares. At one end is Caprica, the starting space for the Galactica, and at the other end is the lost colony of Earth. Every third square is a Planet space and the remaining squares are Deep Space.

The Cylon player is seeking to destroy all of the Galactica’s fighters. The Battlestar player wins if the Galactica makes it to Earth with some fighters left.

36007.name: Big Trouble in Little China Skirmish
36007.description:
A board game based on the John Carpenter film Big Trouble in Little China.

“One player controls Egg Shen and his Allies. The other player controls Lo Pan & his Minions. Each figure represents one Man (Unit). Abstract simulation of the Battle at the end of the Movie. Victory: The Egg Shen player wins if he kills Lo Pan. Lo Pan wins if he kills Egg Shen, Jack Burton, and Wang Chi.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Egg Shen is teamed up with Jack Burton, Wang Chi, and six Chang Sing Fighters. Assisting Lo Pan are the Three Storms (Lightning, Rain, and Thunder), the Chinese Ogre, and eight Wing Kong Fighters.

The players draw hands of cards from a custom deck of 44 cards. Card play determines when units may move or attack.

36008.name: Blitz
36008.description:
“Card game. Simulates the Battle of Britain. July-September 1940. Players will have to make their own sets of cards.
The RAF and Luftwaffe have their own unique decks. Both decks have 62 cards. Notice that most cards have a force value. The Germans also need 20 tokens to represent bomb damage.”

Both players start the game with four cards. The players draw two cards at the start of each turn, with the maximum hand size at the end of the turn being eight cards. The German player has the option not to play a raid, in which case the turn ends. If the German player plays a raid, the players alternate playing force cards until neither player wants to play a card. The strength of the opposing forces are compared. If the RAF has a higher force total, the raid is stopped. If the German has the higher force total, then the amount of bombing damage caused by the raid is determined and added to the German’s score.

“If the German’s accumulate 20 points of bombing damage then they win. Hitler decides to go ahead with operation Sealion. If the German player goes to draw a card and there are no cards left in his deck the British win. Hitler postpones operation Sealion indefinitely.”

36009.name: Buck Rogers
36009.description:
“Welcome to the World of the 25th Century. Help Buck defeat the Han Empire! The Decks: One player gets the Org Deck. The other player gets the Han Deck. Victory: The first player to win 5 hands is the winner.”

Each hand the players fill their hands to seven cards (Arrival Phase), can discard and redraw up to four (Reinforcements Phase), and then the players reveal some, none or all of their cards (Adventure Phase). Each player adds up the Force values of their cards, the player with the higher total wins the hand (Cliffhanger Phase.) The winner of the hand then makes an improvisational narrative of the Episode reflected by the turn using some or all of the cards played as a basis (Narrator Phase.)

36010.name: Buckaroo Banzai
36010.description:
A card game based on the characters and events from the movie The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the Eighth Dimension.

One player plays Team Banzai, the other player is the Red Lectroids. To win the game, be the first player to win eight hands, or win three hands in a row. A hand is won by the player who plays the meld having the highest Action Point total.

36011.name: Cards of Mars
36011.description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Theme is the John Carter of Mars series by Edgar Rice Burroughs. Victory: The first player to accumulate 75 Victory Points (VP) wins. The Deck: Players share a common deck. There are several card types: Heroes, Villains, Beasts, Enemies, Weapons, Plots, Events. All cards fall into one of two categories: Friend cards or Foe cards. All cards have a numerical 'Force' value.”

The players attempt to form eight card melds consisting of at least one Hero or Heroine “Friend Card”, one Plot “Foe Card”, and at least one Enemy or Villain “Foe Card.” Because the good guys always win, the total Force value of the Friends Cards must equal or exceed the Force value of the Foe Cards. The player scores Victory Points equal to the Force value of the Foe Cards played in the meld.

36012.name: Carriers
36012.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. World War Naval/Air II theme. Abstract Fleet & Squadron level combat. Each figure represents a group of Ships or Planes. Victory: You win if you destroy your opponent’s carriers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units, which come in four types: Carriers, Warships, Subs, and Planes. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36013.name: Castle Wolfenstein
36013.description: A solitaire card game inspired by the Wolfenstein 3-D video game. The object of the game is to defeat the six bosses: Hans Grosse, Dr. Shabbs, Hitler Clone, Otto Giftmacher, Gretel Grosse, and General Fettgesicht. Along the way you will also face other Wolfenstein foes – Stormtroopers, Nazi Officers, Attack Dogs, and Zombies. Your hero starts with 20 hits. If you are reduced to zero or less hits, you lose.

36014.description:
A solitaire pencil and paper game which puts the player in the role of a Royal Air Force commander seeking to intercept attacking German aircraft during the Second World War.

“The game combines successful use of radar and RAF fighter resources to intercept German air fleets during the Summer of 1940.” The game is played with a six-sided die, a pencil, and the game sheet. The game lasts fifteen turns.
36014.name: Chain Home

boardgamehonor.40510: 2017 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Expert Nominee

36015.name: Conan
36015.description:
“Create your own tales of Conan the Barbarian and his adventures in Hyboria. All players share a single common deck. The deck contains six suits of cards: Conan cards, Locations, Events, Lesser Foes, Major Foes, & Specials. There are 30+ cards of each suit in the deck.”

The object of the game is to score the most victory points by playing melds from your six card hand. There are four types of melds that may be played: Three Pairs (two cards each from three suits), Two Three-of-a-Kinds (three cards each from two suits), Six-of-a-kind (six cards from one suit), or Flush (one card from each suit).

36016.name: Crack of Doom
36016.description:
“Lord of the Rings Theme. Each player is their own 'Fellowship'. Victory: Players race to see who is the first to destroy the One Ring.”

The game is played on a track 72 spaces long. Designated spaces on the track represent the Shire, Moria, Mordor, Mount Doom, and other Middle Earth locations. Play Foe and Harship Cards on your opponents to hinder their progress. Use Aid Cards to defeat such cards played against you. To win the game, reach the last space on the game track and make a successful die roll to destroy the One Ring.

36017.name: Death in the Sand
36017.description:
“Morocco circa 1925. Berber Tribesmen attack a company of French Foreign Legionnaires. Each player has a unique deck. Victory: The first player to win 4 hands wins the battle.”

Using eight card hands, the players each simultaneously play melds of Leader, Men, Terrain, Weapon, Morale and Tactics Cards. The player who plays the meld with the higher total Force Value wins the hand.

36018.name: Delta Skirmish
36018.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Highly abstracted skirmish level combat. Simulation of a counter-terrorist team operation. One side is the commandos: Delta/SAS/GSG-9/GIGN/etc. The other side is Terrorists holding hostages in a building. Victory: To win the Delta team must kill all the terrorists before taking 4 casualties. The Terrorists win if they kill 4 Delta team members, which allows them time to kill the hostages.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the commandos and terrorists. The terrorist group is composed of one Leader and seven Followers. The commando force consists of one Team Leader, three Shooters, two Demolitions Experts, and two Snipers. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

“The Special Forces have many more cards at their disposal, which reflects their high degree of training & experience.”

36019.description: A card game based on the famous comic strip and movie detective. The game is played with a custom card deck composed of Crime Cards (Criminal, Felony, and Escape Cards) and Law Cards (Dick Tracy, Helper, Investigation, and Pursuit Cards.) The first player to solve three cases is the winner. To solve a case you have to form one of seven types of combos by taking turns drawing and discarding cards.
36019.name: Dick Tracy Files

36020.name: Doctor Strange
36020.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the comic book character Doctor Strange. One player is the forces of good. The other player is the forces of evil. Victory: If, for 2 turns in a row, starting on turn 10, a player has no viable Characters in play, his opponent wins.”

A viable character is one of the player’s character cards that is not Killed, Incapacitated, Exiled, or Captured. Each viable character may make one attack each turn, resolved by die roll and card play. A successful attack can result in the attacker gaining control over one of the opposing player’s character. Characters may also be captured and rescued.

"The Deck: Players share a common deck. Card Types include: Characters, Companions, Locations, Items, Modifiers, Powers, Attacks, Events."

36021.name: Dueling Pistols
36021.description:
“Simulation of a Pistol Duel circa 1700+. Duelists agree to one of the following: One Shot, Multiple Shots (2,3,or 4), First Blood, Death. They may also forgo the Speed element of the Duel and allow the Challenged to fire first.”

The custom deck is divided into four suits: Speed, Aim, Range, and Hit. The Speed cards determine who fires first. Your Aim cards must total higher than your opponent’s Range cards to score a hit. The total of your Hit cards, when compared to those of your opponent, determine whether a player who was hit is wounded or killed.

Your success in the duel falls into one of four categories: “You are Killed: Major Defeat. You are Wounded: Minor Defeat. Opponent Wounded: Minor Victory. Opponent Killed: Major Victory.”

36022.name: Dune
36022.description:
“Atredies vs Harkonnen for control of Dune. Each house starts with 5 Nobles. Victory: If you ever have 5+ more Spice Tokens than your opponent, you win. If you kill all opposing Nobles you win.”

The players attempt to gain control of Dune through card play. Each turn the player who controls Dune gains one Spice Token. House Atredies and House Harkonnen each have Special Abilities which provide die roll bonuses in various game phases.

36023.name: Endless Patrol
36023.description:
“Solo card game. WWII Western Front. Player controls a squad of American GI’s on patrol. Fight German units.”

“The Decks: There are 2 separate decks: The GI Deck and the Patrol Deck. They have separate discard piles.”

“The Squad: Your squad has 15 soldiers. Use tokens to keep track of soldiers.”

“Victory: Get completely through the Patrol Deck. You lose if all of your squad members become casualties.”

36024.name: Escape from LA
36024.description:
“Solo card, dice & board game. Based on the Movie of the same name. Take on the role of Snake Plisskin.”

The game consists of seventeen scenes based on events and characters from the film. To aid in advancing through the scenes, a gameboard with a track of seventeen spaces can be drawn. The player gains cards at various stages. There are four different card types. Each type of card gives a bonus to a different type of die roll.

“Victory: Escape & Activate the Electro-Magnetic Pulse in the last Step. Losing: You lose if you ever get killed, or you do not get the antidote in 10 hours.”

36025.name: F-14 Tomcats
36025.description:
Descriptions from the rules:

“Solo Dice Game. Simulation of an American solo F-14 Bombing Mission in the Middle East circa 1987. Pretty much like Microprose F-15 II. No realism, I think no Tomcat would do a solo bombing mission.”

“Mission: The mission consists 25 waypoints, first and last of which is home base. Draw the waypoints as circles connected with lines on a piece of paper. There are two targets in a mission, primary and secondary targets. First target is 2d6 waypoints from the 1st waypoint, the second 2d6 waypoints from the first target. Roll on the target table to determine what the targets are.”

“Scoring: Keep a running tally of points and kills while you play. You get awarded medals and promotions accordingly. You start with no medals and at a rank of 2nd Lt.”

Rules for a two-player cooperative variant are included.

36026.name: Fantasy Fliers
36026.description:
“Miniatures rules for aerial skirmishes. All combatants (Fliers) include a mount with usually one rider.”

The game features a diverse assortment of aerial combatants, all rated in two classes: Speed and Maneuverability. The Speed rating determines maximum speed, acceleration and deceleration rates, climb and dive rates, and modifiers for dodging and initiative. The Maneuverability rating determines turning rate, dodging ability, and initiative bonus. A wide variety of attack types are provided for: Spell, Poison, Ram, Grab, Petrification/Paralyze, Stun, Web/Net, Mesmerize, Fear, Smoke/Gas, and Fire/Acid Attacks.

With over fifty Mounts described in the game, Fantasy Fliers allows for just about every type of aerial combat you could think of – from bees, wasps, and butterflies to magic carpets, flying skulls, biplanes, and Pegasus.

36027.name: Flying Circus
36027.description:
“Card game for 2 players. WWI Aerial Dogfight Simulation. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies. Victory: The first player to shoot down 4 enemy machines wins the battle. Use coins to keep track of ‘Kills.’”

The game is played using a custom card deck comprised of six suits made up of twelve cards numbered 1 to 12. These suits are Pilots, Allied Planes, German Planes, Tactics, Shooting, and Flying. All of the cards are usable by either player except for the Plane Cards - Allied Planes may only be used by the Allied player and German Planes may only be used by the German player.

Each turn the players are dealt hands of five cards. They may discard and redraw up to three cards. Each player then plays an Attack which must include a Pilot card and a Plane card. An attack may also include one card from each of the other three suits (Shooting, Tactics, and Flying.) A kill is scored when the total value of the cards played in an Attack is equal to or greater than the Attack played by the opposing player.

36028.name: Fokker
36028.description:
“WWI Biplane dog fighting. Get in your Sopwith Camel and take out some Albatrosses. 1 plane per player.” Statistics are provided for four aircraft: Sopwith Camel, Bristol F2b, Fokker D-VII, and Albatros C-V.

The game is played on a hex map. A custom deck of 52 cards is used to regulate combat and maneuvers. The Move Cards provide for left and right turns, hard turns, “slides”, and an Immelman loop.

Aircraft can shoot at any time during their movement by playing a Shoot Card. Aircraft with forward firing guns attack aircraft that are straight ahead, while those with a rearward firing observer can shoot at aircraft in a 60 degree arc of hexes to the rear of the plane. Damage is determined by a die roll modified based on range, which may result in 0 or less damage (indicating a miss).

A Critical Hits occurs when a 1 is rolled on the six-sided die rolled to determine damage. Critical Hits include the death of the observer or pilot, engine damage, critical structural or control damage, and fuel leakage.

The game also includes simple rules for altitude, ammunition, clouds, balloons, and ground fire (infantry, machine gunners, and flak.)

36029.name: Galax
36029.description:
“Tactical Space Ship Combat Mayhem. Advanced Battleships.”

The game is played on a numbered hex grid. Miniatures or chits, marked for facing, are used to represent the spaceships. The players construct their own fleets based on lists of ships and weapon systems. The scenario sets the number of fleet points that each side starts with. Three scenarios are included in the rules.

Movement and combat are simultaneous, based on simple written orders. Combat occurs from the last space a unit enters. The written combat orders consist of indicating the weapon system fired and the mapsheet grid number being targeted. Damage inflicted depends on defensive equipment of the target ship (fields, screens and jammers) and the type of weapon used. Nukes and missiles caused fixed amounts of damage, while energy and projectile weapons have diminished capacity at longer ranges.

Statistics are given for nine types of base ships, ranging from the lowly Transport (used for scenario victory conditions) to the burly Battlestation. Ships are rated for cost, move, hits, number of shields, and number of weapons. Some types of ships can carry Fighter Squads. Ships can be equipped with three types of shields: Albedo Screens (protect against energy weapons), Intertia Fields (protect against projectile weapons), and Jammers (protect against missiles.) Weapon systems that can be purchased include Lasers, Rail Guns, Missile Launchers, Missiles, and Nuclear Missiles.

36030.name: Gambler
36030.description:
“Card & Dice game for 2+ players. Each player is a Gambler trying to win Big. Victory: The Winner is the first player to accumulate $5,000. If you ever lose all your money, you lose the game.” Each player starts with $5000. Pennies or other tokens are used as money, each being worth $100.

The game uses a custom set of cards. There are five types of cards in the deck: Casino Game Bets (Black Jack, Poker, Craps, & Roulette), Race Track Bets (Dogs, Horses, Jai Alai), Sports Bets (Baseball, Basketball, & Football), Win Cards and Special Cards.

Each turn a player plays a Bet card and rolls on a 2d6 Wager Table to determine the result. Win Cards can be played to modify the result. Multiple Casino and Sports bets may be made in one turn, but Casino and Track bets may not be made in the same turn. Special cards are played at the end of a player’s turn and add $100-$600 to a player’s bankroll as determined by a die roll.

The designer notes that the game is based on the gambling practices of his father and uncles.

36031.name: Gamma World the Card Game

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

36031.description:
“Card Game based on the RPG Gamma World by TSR. You are a leader of a Gamma World Enclave. Recruit and equip your followers. Send your followers to capture ruins that will aid your cause. Victory: The game ends when all cards have been drawn from the deck. The player controlling the most location cards wins.”

The game uses a custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Weapons, Armor, Vehicles, Steeds, Equipment, Events, Mutations, Foes, and Locations.

Each turn a player receives a base allocation of two Action Points. Some cards will provide additional Action Points. Action Points are spent to perform the following actions: recruit one Follower, draw one card from the deck, play an Item card, or attack a Location.

36032.name: Geonosis Arena Skirmish
36032.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between Jedi knights & Federation allies on Genosis. Takes place in the Star Wars Universe (Episode II). Each figure represents a Hero, Jedi, Creature or Unit of Troops. Victory: The game ends after you go through the deck twice when Yoda and the clone trooper gunships arrive. The player who has killed the most opposing units wins.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. There are ten Jedi units, twenty-two Federation units, and three Creature units.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend. The Creatures in the arena are not allied with the Jedi or Federation. Either player may cause Creatures to Move or Attack by playing Creature Cards.

36033.name: Gerrymandering
36033.description:
“Players take turns changing the district lines in order to win the election.”

The game is played on a 10x10 grid. Each square represents a city block. At the start of the game, 100 Block Chits are randomly placed on the map. These Block Chits are randomly created by rolling for four characteristics: Income, Party, Race, and Issues.

Each player supports a candidate running for office. The candidate has eight profile characteristics: Income, Party, Race, two Allied Races, and three Issues ranked for priority.

There are four phases to the game. In the first phase, district lines are drawn by the players taking turns placing 1d6 District Markers on the map until all fifty District Markers have been placed. In the second phase, District Lines are redrawn – the players are able to move a randomly determined number of District Markers.

The third phase is the Census, in which the Block characteristics of the fifty blocks marked as part of the District are totaled. The fourth phase is the Election, in which the District votes for each candidate are calculated based on the Census data and the profile characteristics of the candidates.

The player whose candidate gets the most votes in the election wins the game.

36034.description:
“VOW OF THE GLADIATOR: I submit to being burned, chained, beaten, and killed with an iron weapon."

“Supplemental meta-game for Gladius. Players are masters of their own gladiator schools. Buy them, train them, and send them to the arena.”

The players start with 50 gold and one gladiator. Slaves come up for auction and are bid on by the players. The players then match up gladiators to be fought using the Gladius card game rules. Each player involved in the fight receives an award of gold, the amount of which varies based on whether the match was won or lost, and for each of their gladiators that fought animals.

The players must pay a regular upkeep cost for every gladiator owned. Gold may also be spent to enhance the training of gladiators.

Fame Points are awarded to players at the end of each turn based on factors such as owning the most gladiators, having the most gold, and winning matches. The player with the most Fame Points after twenty turns wins the game.
36034.name: Gladiator School

36035.description:
A rules supplement designed to be used in conjunction with the Gladius card game and its supplement Gladiator School.

The Miniatures Rules “provide a way of using miniature figures to show the relative distance between the fighters and give the game a little more color and realism with only a moderate increase in complexity. The only extra equipment needed for this variant are miniatures representing the gladiators and a rectangular card (the Display) that is divided into three equal parts across its length.”
36035.name: Gladius Miniatures

36036.name: Gunslingers
36036.description:
“Board, dice, & card game for 2+ players. Wild West Theme. Battle between gunslingers. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill all enemy gunslingers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Chits are used to indicate terrain features. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the gunslingers. There are seven types of gunslingers represented in the game: Cowboy, Outlaw, Indian, Lawman, Soldier, Pistol, and Rifle. Each type of gunslinger is rated for seven attributes, including Guts, Smarts, Cool, Eyes, and Hands.

The Action Deck is a custom deck of cards central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards for each gunslinger from this common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Optional rules are provided for horses, shotguns, and carrying multiple guns.

36037.name: Go Joe
36037.description:
“G.I. Joe vs Cobra. 2 player game: Board, Cards, Dice. There are 2 decks. One player gets the Joe Deck. The other player gets the Cobra Deck. Victory: You win if you ever capture your opponent’s base, or you control all ‘Urban’ spaces on the board.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid with spaces large enough to hold a card. The G.I. Joe base is in one corner of the board and the Cobra base is in the opposite corner. The remaining 62 spaces are a random mix of eight terrain types: Jungle, Swamp, Sea, Desert, Mountain, Forest, Urban, and Arctic.

Each player starts with four Teams and a hand of cards. Each card has the name and statistics for a soldier. The cards are placed under each Team counter to represent the soldiers in that Team.

Teams engage in combat by moving into the same space as an opposing Team. Combat is resolved based on one of three unit factors (as determined randomly by a die roll): Firepower, Close Combat, or Tactics. Combat bonuses are given for various factors, including having a team with soldiers from the same service branch or when units are defending their base. Combat resolution also takes into consideration artillery units, armor units vs. anti-armor, and air units vs. “anti-air.”

36038.name: Gundam Wing
36038.description:
A miniatures game based on the Mobile Suit Gundam universe.

The game includes statistics for over 50 different Mobile Suits from seven different Factions. In addition, the rules allow you to design your own Mobile Suits.

Eleven different generic Suit classes are defined, each of which is rated for Move Points, Hits, and Size Class (Small, Medium, and Large.) Seven classes of Weapons Systems are provided in the rules, with each being rated for Size, Damage, Range, Ammo, and Cost. The combat rules include hand-to-hand combat and critical hits.

36039.name: Guild Master
36039.description:
“Players take the role of founding fathers of a medieval town. The best builder earns the title of Guild Master.”

The game is played with a custom deck of 116 cards. Each card specifies a type of Location and the Resources it provides. Some cards also specify additional Resources that are provided when they are combined with other specific Location cards.

Players obtain cards by drawing them from the deck and trading. On each turn, a player declares which type of Resource category to build, and then plays any cards of that category.

The game ends at the end of the turn that the last card is drawn from the deck. The winner is the player whose town provides the highest scores in the most number of Resource categories.

36040.name: Ground War 3000
36040.description:
“Sci-Fi themed board & card game for 2 players. Each figure represents a vehicle, mech, or infantry squad. Victory: You rout the enemy if you destroy 9+ of his units.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each side starts with sixteen units: two Mechs, six Vehicles, and eight Infantry.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend. In addition, Obstacle cards may be played in response to movement cards, sometimes casuing the moving unit to sustain damage. Other special cards allow a unit to both move and attack in the same turn.

36041.name: Grognards
36041.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Napoleonic warfare theme. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Victory: You rout the enemy if you destroy 9+ of his units.”

The game is played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each side starts with sixteen units: eight Infantry, four Cavalry, and four Artillery. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

Optional rules provide for terrain, which comes in six types: Clear, Deep Water, Forest, Hill, Redoubt, and Marsh. The terrain features impact movement and combat in various ways.

36042.name: Grendel & Beowulf
36042.description:
“Board Game for 2 players. One player takes the role of the Hero Beowulf. The other player takes the role of the Monster Grendel. Victory: Slay your Foe. The first player to reduce his opponent to zero or less hits wins. Each player starts the game with 20 Hit Points.”

The game board is a track 13 spaces long. Each space on the board is a named location. These range from the Great Hall and other places favorable to the Danes at one end, to the dangerous swamps at the opposite end which favor Grendel.

Attack, Defense, and Ally Cards are used in combat. The other cards are used to perform various functions, such as assisting in travel or healing wounds. Some cards may be used to impede your opponent’s travel or to require your opponent to discard cards.

36043.name: Grenadier Tactics
36043.description: The game is played using two custom decks – an Army Deck and a Battle Deck. The Army Deck consists of units (Infantry Company, Cavalry Platoon, or Artillery Battery), each of which is rated for Attack Damage and Defense. The Battle Deck consists of Attack Cards, Opportunity Attack Cards, Defense Cards, Event Cards, Leader Cards, and Terrain Cards. Each player starts with a random draw of five Army Cards and five Battle Cards. Variant rules are included for a quick start, balanced starting forces, and alternate victory conditions.

36044.name: Green Plastic Massacre
36044.description:
“Combat rules for plastic Army men."

"Armies start at opposite ends of the room. Turn Sequence: Each figure gets to move once and attack once per turn. Mortars, machine guns & artillery can either move or attack during a turn.”

Several different combat resolution mechanisms are included in the rules. The mechanism to be used depends on the nature of the attacking unit. For instance, a submachinegun attack is resolved as follows: “Standing 15 feet away from the target throw 3 marbles simultaneously.” On the other hand, for a flamethrower: “Stand over the attacker. Drop a tennis ball from the tip of your nose.”

In addition, a six-sided die is rolled to determine what means is used to resolve hand-to-hand attacks between infantry units within two inches of each other. The die roll may call for these conflicts to be resolved by means such as arm wrestling, a staring contest, or rock-paper-scissors.

The “Safety Rules” note that players should wear goggles at all times.

36045.name: Greek Games
36045.description:
“Card game for 2-4 players. Ancient Greek Olympics Theme. Players try to win the most Events. Victory: The player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins.”

The game is played using two decks. The Ability Deck contains sixty cards. The Event Deck specifies the twelve events in which the players will compete, which include Discus, Javelin, Horse Racing, and Boxing.

The Ability cards played by the players determine who will be awarded the Gold, Silver, and Bronze medals in each event.

36046.description:
“Wargame for 2 or more players. Mythological Greek theme. Victory: Occupy all 6 City States on the Board.”

“Tiles are used to make the Map. Chits are used to represent Units. Cards are used for Events. Counters are stacked with units to record damage. Tile, chit, counter, and card sets are common to all players. Six sided dice are needed to play.”

The map is generated by randomly distributing the Terrain Tiles on a chess board or 8x8 grid. The Tiles come in two water varieties (Sea, Abyss) and five land varieties (Coastal, City State, Forest, Mountains, Ruins.)

Each player starts the game with one Hero unit located on a City State space. The players must recruit various heroes, men, and monsters to aid them in their conquest of Greece. The players will face random events reflecting the blessings of the Greek Gods or disasters and dangers.
36046.name: Grecos

36047.name: Grail
36047.description:
“Fantasy Card game. 2-6 players. Players take the role of Arthurian Knights on the quest for the Holy Grail. Object: The first player to accumulate 7 'Quest' tokens is the winner.”

“Materials: There are 65 cards in the deck. Players will have to create their own cards in order to play. A six sided die is required to play. 7 'quest tokens' per player are needed.”

Each player’s turn consists of two to four phases. In the Draw Phase, two cards a drawn. This is followed by the Fate phase, in which the player decides whether or not to quest for the grail. If the player declines to quest, the turn ends.

If a player decides to quest, the Adventure Phase comes next. The opponent to the left of the phasing player may play a Test Card. If the phasing player is able to pass the Test, then the other opponents may continue to play Test Cards against the phasing player. This continues until no opponents offer a Test Card. If any Test is failed, the turn ends. If all Tests are met, then the Quest Phase follows. Quests are resolved based on a die roll combined with Aid cards played by the phasing player.

“If you accumulate 7 Quest tokens, than you are deemed worthy to receive the Holy Grail, and you win.”

36048.name: Golden Axe
36048.description:
“Solitaire Card game. Based on the side-scroller video game of the same name.”

The player starts with five characters, a Warrior, Dwarf, Woman Warrior, Sprite, and Centaur. Each character is rated for Hits, Magic, Speed, Damage Bonus, and Weapon.

The card deck contains six types of cards: Attack, Defend, Heal, Speed, Magic, and Foe. The player must defeat a series of Foes to reach and confront the Death Adder. The player wins the game by defeating the Death Adder.

36049.name: Gods & Demons
36049.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on Hindu Mythology. One player is the Good Blue Skinned Rama. The other is the Evil 10-headed, 40-Armed Demon King Ravana. Victory: Kill the opposing Leader.”

Each player has a unique deck containing, in addition to one Leader card, eight basic card types: Heroes, Troops, Weapons, Armor, Modifiers, Strikes, Defenses, and Events.

Players can hold a hand of up to eight cards. The players alternate being the attacker, at which time they have the option of choosing to attack with some, all, or no units. The defender chooses which units will block attacking units. All unblocked units attack the opposing leader. Damage markers are used to record combat results.

36050.name: Goblin Quest
36050.description:
“Teams of Goblins run around, get into mischief, wreak havoc, and try to not get killed. Not unlike Space Scouts.”

The game is played using a custom deck containing four types of cards: Mission, Threat, Mishap, and Aid. Each player starts with four Goblin characters, each of which has two to three skills.

The object of the game is to be the first player to accumulate a specific number of Victory Points. Victory Points are gained by completing Missions (the amount awarded depending on the difficulty) and overcoming Threats. Victory Points may be spent to give your Goblin characters new skills and to replace a Goblin character than has been lost.

36051.name: Goblin Commander Tactics
36051.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the video game of the same name. Victory: Destroy all of your opponent’s units.”

Each player portrays one of five Clans. Each Clan has an individual deck of Clan Units. The players share a common Magic Deck and Tactics Deck. The players deploy Clan Card units onto the battlefield by playing them on the table. Each Clan Card is allowed to make one attack each turn.

36052.name: Global Warming
36052.description:
“Solo card game. Abstract simulation of Global Warming. Winning & Losing: If the Heat Level ever gets to 10, Global Warming is not controlled and Civilization as we know it is doomed. If at the End of the game the Heat Level is 9 or below, humanity has averted complete disaster. The Game ends when there are no cards left in the Heat Deck.”

The game is played using a custom deck of cards made up of four suits: Pollution, Consequences, Political Will, and Solutions. Each suit had thirteen cards numbered from one to thirteen. A normal deck of cards can be used if the player does not wish to construct the custom deck.

36053.name: Gettysburg
36053.description:
“American Civil War card game for 2 players. Gettysburg: 1-3 July, 1863. The biggest battle ever fought on the soil of North America. One side is the Union, the other is the Confederacy.” The game is played with a custom card deck. The cards portray the military leaders, weapons, locations, and events which played a part in the conflict.

Each round the players take turns playing cards or combinations. The player whose cards have the higher Force value wins the round. Ties are won by the Union player. The first player to win five rounds wins the game.

36054.name: GeneRally
36054.description:
Based on the PC auto racing game of the same name.

“A cardgame for 2 to 6 players. It tries to recreate some of the twists of the original PC game, but incorporates more than that: card management, timing of card play, bluff.”

“The game is played on four regular rounds and a great Final Lap round. The regular rounds are the main moves of the race, where the players will struggle to better their positions on the race. The Final Lap round will be the outcome of all the tactics and choices made during the race . . . The winner of the race is the player which car has moved furthest on the track.”

The rules are in English, Italian, and French.

36055.name: General Backgammon
36055.description:
“2 Player Dice and Board Game. Backgammon Variant with specialized pieces. Napoleonic Military Theme.”

The game is played on a regular Backgammon board. Each player uses three six-sided dice and has a set of sixteen pieces composed of four Infantry, two each of Skirmishers, Horse Artillery, Field Artillery, Light Cavalry, and Heavy Cavalry, one General and one Lines of Communication. Units are rated for two capabilities – shoot and move. In addition, each type of unit has one or more Special Abilities.

There are five types of victory: Strategic - capture your opponent’s Lines of Communication Unit; Morale - kill or capture your opponent’s General and 4+ other Units; Attrition - destroy any 8+ enemy Units; Outflank - have 4+ of your units on your opponent’s back six points; and Positional - have 8+ of your units on your opponent’s front six points.

36056.name: Gearhead Skirmish
36056.description:
“2 Armies of Wind-up toys duke it out. Based on an old video game. Victory: Players get 1 point every time a toy goes off their opponent’s side of the board. The game ends when the counter pile is empty and there are no toys left on the board (or no toy has been able to move in 5 turns.) The player with the most points wins the game.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Six and eight-sided dice are required. There are twelve wind-up toys in the game, each with its own counter.

At the beginning of the game, all of the toy counters are placed in a cup or face down in a pile. At the start of a player’s turn, a toy counter is drawn and placed at that player’s end of the board. Each of the player's toys moves once. The type of move each piece can make is determined by a die roll.

36057.name: Garden Grow
36057.description:
“Players compete to see who can grow the best garden. Victory: At the end of the game, the player who scores the highest in the most plant categories is the winner. Game End: The game ends when at the end of a players turn, there are no cards left in the deck.”

The game uses a custom deck composed of ten categories of cards: eight Plant Categories, the Nurture Category, and the Blight Category.

36058.name: Gangs of New York Skirmish
36058.description:
“Dead Rabbits vs Bowery Boys. Simulation of an all out Street Melee between two rival NY urban gangs circa 1864. Victory: Kill your opponents Leader.”

The game is played on a 6x8 grid (it may be convenient to use a portion of a chess board). Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player starts with sixteen units: one Leader, seven Axers, and eight Knifers.

Each turn both players roll five six-sided dice. Each die result corresponds to one of six possible moves listed on the Result chart (such as “1 - One knifer may kill an opponent in an orthogonally adjacent space” or “5 - Move one of your men two spaces in any direction.”) The players alternate using one die result to make a move. After both players have used their five dice, the next turn begins and the process is repeated.

36059.description:
“PREMISE: This plays like a cross between Chess and Backgammon. SET UP: Regular Chessboard and pieces plus two dice. OBJECT: Move all of your men to your opponents back row.”

Each turn a player rolls two dice to determine which pieces may be moved (a chart assigns each number on a d6 to one type of chess piece). Pieces may only be moved forward or sideways, not backward. However, a piece can only capture when it is moving forwards. When a piece is captured it is returned to the back row of the owning player.

A short-game variant provides that the game is won by the first player to move a King off the board.
36059.name: Gamma Chess

36060.name: Game of Lists
36060.description:
“Trivia game for 1 or more players. Winning: The first player to score 35 points is the winner.”

The game consists of a custom deck of cards. Each card describes a category. A card is drawn and the players are given a set amount of time to write a list of items that come within the category. Once the time limit has expired, the players reveal their lists. Each correct answer scores one point, but a player may not score more than ten points in a single turn.

Categories on the cards include: Names of Physicists, Names of Cuts of Beef, Names of Computer Programming Languages, Names of Antibiotics, Names of Bad Guys in Star Wars and The First 10 Elements on the Periodic Table.

36061.name: Galactic Supremacy
36061.description:
“You guessed it. Rival space empires are at it again. A card game for 2 or more players.” The object of the game is to capture the Homeworlds of all your opponents. The game is played with a custom deck of 75 cards.

The players earn Credits by controlling Sectors of space. Credits may be used to open new Sectors and to put Fleets and Leaders into play. Credits may also be used to research one of the nine types of technology. The level of technological development plays into the combat system, which is the means by which enemy fleets and sectors are destroyed and Homeworlds are captured.

36062.name: Galactic Civilizations
36062.description:
A game of alien conquest played on a 10x10 grid, with each square representing a sector of space.

Eight major alien civilizations inhabit the galaxy. Each player represents four Client alien races as determined by random card draw at the start of the game. At the start of the game, each alien race controls one randomly selected sector. Each race has special abilities/limitations that affect the general rules of play, as well as special victory conditions which establish additional criteria by which the players may earn extra Victory Points.

The player with the most victory points at the end of 2d10 turns wins the game. Victory points are scored for each sector controlled by a player’s Client alien races.

36063.name: Fusillade
36063.description: “Two-player card game of Napoleonic Warfare. Players share a common deck. The deck contains three types of cards: Unit, Tactics, and Strategy. Each player starts with 100 points of troops. Use change to keep track of troop points. Victory: Reduce your opponent’s troop total to zero.” Troop casualties are inflicted by successfully playing cards during the Attack Phase.

36064.name: Freudian Slip
36064.description: “Players immerse themselves in a mass psychosis directed by the cards and their own subconscious desires.” Players are dealt seven cards, each displaying one word. “The player with the most psychological baggage goes first.” The players take turns describing a dream, incorporating a word from one of their cards. The game ends when two players pass their turns. The player who is voted the winner in the most categories “is declared the most in need of Psychoanalysis.”

36065.name: French Revolution
36065.description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Simulation of the French Revolution (starting 1789). Victory: The first player to accumulate 10 Reform points is able to consolidate the Revolution and wins the game. Setup: The most ‘French’ player begins as the leader of the Revolution.”

The game is played using a custom card deck made up of five different types of cards: Unrest, Revolutionary Tactics, Reforms, Oppression (Reactionary Tactics), and Anti-Revolutionary. Reform points are scored by first playing Unrest, Tactics, and Oppression Cards to become or remain the leader of the revolution, and then playing Reform Cards, each of which scores one Reform point. Opposing players may negate a Reform card by playing an Anti-Revolutionary card.

36066.name: French Indian Wars
36066.description:
“Card Game for 2 Players. French Indian War Theme circa 1753-1763.”

One player takes on the role of the British forces, the other player is the French. The game is played with a custom deck of cards. The cards include leaders, troops, Indians, and defenses.

The object of the game is to win all of the forts, represented by Fort Tokens. At the start of the game each player has five Fort Tokens. The Tokens are won when the Attacking player is able to play the winning cards in the Expedition and Siege phases of a turn. Solitaire and optional rules are included.

36067.name: Freebooter
36067.description:
“Adventure on the High Seas in the Golden Age of Piracy.”

The players are pirates seeking to be the first to retrieve the treasure at the center of the board and return it to the start space. The board is a 7x7 grid made into a path which spirals toward the center. The route is filled with plenty of hardships and hostile warships. In addition, the pirates are constantly pursued by Bounty Hunter ships, privateers under the service of the King.

36068.name: Freddy vs. Jason Skirmish
36068.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the Supernatural Horror Movies. One player is Freddie, the other is Jason.”

The game uses a custom deck containing ten types of cards: Location, Victim, Attack, Fire Attack, Death Blow Attack, Trap, Escape, Heal, Inspiration and Special cards. You win the game by reducing your opponent’s Hit Points to zero.

36069.name: Asimov's Foundation and Empire War Game
36069.description:
“This is a four player war game set during Asimov's Foundation and Empire Novel. Each player controls a quadrant of the Milky Way Galaxy: (Listed from Terminus, going Spinward) The Foundation, The Imperium, The Union Of Worlds (The Mule) and Tazenda.”

The first player to occupy thirteen Sectors with Major Systems wins the game. Solitaire rules are also included. The game portrays combat between interstellar fleets using a diceless combat resolution system.

36070.name: Formula Ace Racing Pods
36070.description:
“This game is a futuristic race of the WipeOut or Star Wars episode 1 kind.”

“A single championship is made of one or several circuits. Except if otherwise voted by all players, all circuit will have to be played three time, once for each category. Each race belongs to one special category and has special rules and only the third one allows the use of weapons. Categories are: Total Speed Way - a speed race where the initial risks bidding is essential, Dragster Show - an die-fast competition where wreckage are far from being uncommon, Destruction Derby - where the pilots are allowed weapons aboard.”

There are four different kinds of racing ships, each rated for Speed, Hit Points, and “Space Available” for further customization. Pilots are rated for Piloting and G-Endurance.

36071.name: Flower Power
36071.description:
“Party Game. Relive the 60s or experience them for the first time.”

The players move down the game track and collect tokens reflecting the following types of experiences: Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll, Political Activism, and Self Actualization. A separate game track represents a “Vietnam War Tour of Duty.” A player wins the game by having the highest scores in the most of the five experience areas.

36072.name: Flintloque Skirmish
36072.description:
“Zombie Cossacks, Elven Grognards, Dwarf Landwehr, Drow Fusiliers, Orc Hussars... Fantasy in the Age of Muskets. Card Game for 2+ players.” Inspired by the Flintloque miniatures rules.

The game is played using a common deck of Strategy cards and custom Army Decks for each of the four armies: Ferach High Elf Grand Armee, Albion Orc Army, Krautian Dwarf Army, and the Witchlands Undead Army. Each player holds a hand of Strategy Cards and a hand of Army Cards. The players deploy units and set up attacks by playing cards. Combat is resolved by die roll. The first player to “send 10 enemy Units to their graves” wins the game.

36073.name: Fleets of the Imperium
36073.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Space Combat in the Games Workshop Warhammer 40K Space Fleet Universe. Pick your Fleet: Tyranid, Imperial, Eldar, or Necron. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship.”

The game is played on a chessboard or other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each player has a fleet of sixteen ships comprised of one flagship and four other types of ships, which vary depending on the type of fleet chosen. Each ship is rated for hits, movement, and size.

Each type of fleet uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from their decks. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36074.name: Fix Bayonets
36074.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. WWI Theme. Abstract skirmish level combat. Man to Man fighting in the Argonne Forest 1918. One player is the defending American Lost Battalion. The other player is the attacking German Stormtroopers. Victory: You win if you kill both of your opponents Officers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each player starts with the following assortment of sixteen units: two Officers, ten Riflemen, two Heavy Weapon Specialists, one Runner, and one Sniper.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move and attack. Terrain cards may be used to defeat attack or movement cards.

36075.name: Five Armies
36075.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between the Free Peoples & the Goblinfolk for control of Smaug’s treasure at the end of the Hobbit (by JRR Tolkein). Each figure represents a warband of many troops. Victory: You win if you kill off 10+ of your opponents units.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units – Dwarves, Elves, Men and Eagles for the Free Peoples, and Trolls, Orcs, Goblins and Wargs for the Goblinfolk. Each player starts with a set force of sixteen units. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from this shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36076.description:
Two groups of fish battle for supremacy.

Each player starts with a set of sixteen fish (two each of eight different kinds) which square off on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Each turn a player rolls two dice and moves up to two fish the distance shown on a die.

The fish are rated with Force values ranging from 0 to 7. A fish with a higher Force value can eat a fish with a lower Force value by landing on it. However, two weaker fish can be positioned to eliminate a stronger fish when their combined Force totals are equal to or greater than that of the larger fish.

The three weakest fish have special abilities – the Flying Fish can jump over other fish, the Minnow can use both die rolls in one turn, and the Puffer cannot be eaten.

The winner is the player who eliminates all opposing edible fish or who occupies all four center spaces of the board at the end of the opponent’s turn.
36076.name: Fish Food

36077.name: Firestorm
36077.description:
“When two forest fires collide... a ferocious storm unleashes its fury. You must stop the flames at all costs. Do you have what it takes to fight the biggest wildfire of this century? Or are you too busy cowering beneath your computer desk?”

“Solo card game. Also designed for 2 or more players to compete against each other for best score. Each player is in command of an Army of wildfire fighters & equipment. Protect structures from fire damage to accumulate points.”

The game uses two decks of cards. The Battle Card deck is a custom deck consisting of Fighter Cards (different kinds of firefighting crews and equipment), Aid Cards, Challenge Cards, and Leader Cards. The Flame Deck represents the fire and structures or victims using a standard deck of playing cards (including jokers.) The object of the game is to have the most structures once there are no more Flame Cards in the deck or all flames are extinguished.

36078.name: Firebase Nam
36078.description:
A card game based on a tactical battle in the Vietnam War. One player is responsible for defending a U.S. firebase, the other controls the attacking VC/NVA units. Each player uses a custom deck which is made up of cards representing combat units, fortifications, supply, tactics and morale.

Each turn the players build hands of cards. The player with the hand having the highest combined force total wins the round.

The player who wins the most hands out of 9 wins the game, except that if either player wins 3 hands in a row then the game ends in a victory for that player.

36079.name: Fighting Front
36079.description:
A World War II themed game played using cards placed on a 5x6 grid. The players portray one of five nationalities: German, Russian, American, or Japanese. At the start of the game, each player controls one half of the board.

The cards in the deck represent combat units, leaders, locations, and events. The types of combat units represented in the game include air, armor, and infantry forces of various types. While both sides play from a common deck, there are six types of cards in the deck that provide a various nationality specific unit or effect.

The first player to have units occupying two or more spaces in the opposing player’s back row wins the game.

36080.name: Faiths
36080.description:
Each player represents a major religion attempting to spread throughout the population of over more than half of the territories on a map depicting the Middle East and Asia. The game is played using a custom deck containing two types of cards: Magnitude Cards and Event Cards.

The religions represented in the game, and their starting territories, are as follows: Shinto (Japan), Taoism (South China), Confucianism (North China), Buddhism (South India), Jainism (North India), Hinduism (East India), Sikhism (West India), Zoroastrianism (Iran), Islam (Arabia), Judaism (South Israel), Christianity (North Israel).

36081.name: Fading Suns Emperor Wars
36081.description:
“Card game for 5 players. Based on the 1995 SF PC Game Emperor of the Fading Suns.”

In this detailed game of interplanetary struggle and conquest, each player is the leader of a Noble House who is seeking to become the Emperor. Each player starts with control of a Noble House, five random planets, five Scepters, and a War Fleet. Each Noble House has a unique bonus.

The object of the game is to hold the position of Regent for four consecutive turns. The first player to do so is declared Emperor. The Regent is selected by vote of the players, with each Scepter they hold being worth one vote. In addition, a player with the favor of the Church or Guilds may vote with Scepters controlled by those groups. In the case of a tie vote, no player serves as Regent that turn. Scepters can be obtained from other players by making successful attacks.

36082.name: Exploration in the Age of Sail
36082.description:
“Card game for 2-4+ players. Theme of Exploration during the 15th to 18th Centuries.”

“There are 2 Decks: The Expedition Deck. The Exploration Deck.”

“There are 4 types of cards in the Expedition Deck: Explorer, Ship, Crew, Save. There are 3 types of cards in the Exploration Deck: Ocean, Hazard, Discovery. The Discovery cards themselves when claimed serve as a record of Discovery Points (DP). Discovery cards you claim are kept in your Victory pile.”

“Victory: The player with the most discovery points at the end of the game is the winner. End of Game: The game ends when the Exploration deck has been gone through twice.”

36083.description:
“Card, Board, & Dice game for 2-4+ players. Each player is an Eskimo (Inuit) Hunter.”

The game is played on a circular track of 16 spaces. There are three types of spaces on the board: shelter, hunting grounds, and ice. Two decks of cards are used, the Animal Deck and the Hunter Deck. The Animal Deck is composed of the animals that may be captured by the players. The Hunter Deck is composed of weapons, means of transportation, and special cards.

“Winning: At the end of the game, the player with the most Food Points wins. Food points are gained by collecting (hunting) Animal cards. The game ends when all Animal cards have been collected. Get 1 Food Point for each Special card in your hand at the end of the game.”
36083.name: Eskimo

36084.description:
“These solo rules are based on an essentially romantic view of the eskimo and hopefully compliment the multi player Eskimo card and board game by Lloyd Krassner. Why solo??? - No one to play with, thats why.”

In addition to splitting the board into the real world and underworld halves, this solitaire variant also adds Fate Cards, Skills and Seasons to the game.

“The solo rules are 1 year in the life of your eskimo. One year is 16 steps of the season track.”

“The upper world (realworld) is bad luck, accident, misadventure and occasionally good luck. To survive you need to manage your resources, your personal strengths, acquire skills and deal with misfortune.”

“The other world is taboo, transgression, animal guides and recovering your balance in your world.”

“You need both to survive. You will need to travel in both worlds and maintain balance.”
36084.name: Eskimo Expansion

36085.name: Enclave
36085.description:
“Players lead post-holocaust armies in a battle for survival.” The object of the game is to occupy your opponent’s Enclave.

The game is played on a 6x6 grid with each player occupying an Enclave at a corner of the board (at opposite corners if there are only two players). The nature of the territory in every other space is unknown until revealed by exploration. The different types of territory chits bestow various bonuses. The game features Road Warrior type gangs and vehicles, including cycle gangs and a gyrocopter.

36086.name: Emporex
36086.description:
“Players take the roles of rival Noble Houses in a war to control a neutral space sector.” The object of the game is to be the first player to control every planet on the map.

The game is played on a 10x10 hex grid, with the Homeworlds located in the corners. The other 20 planets are randomly distributed by rolling 10 sided dice to determine coordinates. All of the planets and Homeworlds are named and rated for type, income produced, and combat units available on the planet. Each player begins with identical forces, including randomly determined allies. The allies represent galactic powers that provide certain bonuses, units, or special capabilities.

36087.description:
An abstract strategy game with an “Earth, Air, Water, Fire Theme.” The game is played using 24 pieces on a standard 8x8 chess board.

Each piece is associated with one of the four elements. A piece cannot capture pieces of its own element, only those of different elements. For example, Air pieces can only capture Water and Fire pieces; Water pieces can only capture Fire and Earth pieces; Fire pieces can only capture Earth and Air pieces; and Earth pieces can only capture Air & Water pieces.

You win if you capture all six of your opponent’s pieces of any one element.
36087.name: Elemental Chess

36088.name: Eagles of Glory
36088.description:
“Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare. The first player to be routed from 3 of his 5 forward positions loses.”

The game is played using three custom card decks: the Battalion Deck, Tactics Deck, Commander Deck. Cards are played on the table in opposing lines representing positions on the center, left and right center, and left and right flanks of the battlefield. The game includes scenarios for Maida (4-7-1806), Bussaco (27-9-1810), and Quatre Bras (16-06-1815).

36089.name: Dumbledore's Army
36089.description:
“Based on the battle at the end of Harry Potter & the Order of the Phoenix. Battle between Dumbledore & his Followers vs Voldemort & his Death Eaters. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single wizard. Victory: The Dumbledore player wins if Voldemort is ‘defeated’. The Voldemort player wins if Dumbledore or Harry is ‘defeated’.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the wizards. The Dumbledore player has twelve wizards and the Voldemort player has thirteen. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36090.name: Dragon Slayers
36090.description:
“One player takes the role of the Dragon. The other player takes the role of the Slayer (the adventuring party trying to slay the dragon). There are 2 decks: The Dragon Deck. The Slayer Deck.”

The Slayer player starts with up to eight randomly selected characters and/or artifacts. The Slayer plays cards to attack the dragon which the Dragon player may attempt to block. The Dragon player then has the opportunity to attack one or more members of the Slayer Party.

“Victory: If the Dragon is reduced to 0 or less Hit Points the Slayers win. If all party members are killed, the Dragon wins. The Dragon has 10 hit points. Party Members (Slayers: Heroes & Men-at-Arms) have 1 hit point each. Each unblocked attack by the Dragon will kill one party member. Unblocked attacks by Slayers cause 1 or more hit points of damage to the Dragon.”

36091.name: Dragon Lance Companions
36091.description:
“Takes place 300+ years after the great cataclysm in the world of Krynn. Guide the Companions of the Lance in their exploration of the ruins of Xak Tsaroth to retrieve the Disks of Mishakal needed to defeat Takhisis, the Queen of Darkness. Players share a common deck.”

Each turn the player is seeking to capture a foe by playing a foe card along with Hero and Aid cards having a force value higher than the Foe card. The captured Foe card is placed in the player’s Victory Pile and the Hero and Aid Cards go in the discard pile.
“Game End: The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck and everyone passes their turn without capturing a Foe card. Victory: The player with the highest Force total in his Victory pile wins the game.”

36092.name: Doctor Who
36092.description:
“Players take the role of Renegade Time Lords working for the Celestial Intervention Agency. Players must work cooperatively to foil the plots of Temporal Marauders. The goals of Temporal Marauders are the destruction or conquest of Gallifrey, Nexus point Earth, or the Universe.”

“There are two decks in the game: The Time Lord Deck, and the Temporal Marauder Deck. All players share both decks.”

“If the players go completely through the Temporal Marauder Deck and defeat all the Marauders, they share a combined win. The player with the most lives + cards in his Victory pile is the first place winner. The next is the second place winner, and so on.”

“If any Marauder Card ever gets 4 plot tokens on it, the time line is irreversibly disrupted, resulting in universal disaster. Time and Space unravel. All players lose. Game over.”

36093.name: Devastators 3000
36093.description:
“The high tech version of Devastators 2500. The larger Interstellar warships go by many categorical names:
Dreadnaughts, Battlers, Star Cruisers, and of course, Devastators. Each player controls a Devastator, or ship, represented by his deck. Play pits Devastator vs Devastator. Run out your opponent’s deck to destroy his ship.”

The game uses a custom deck with over 100 cards. The object of the game is to destroy the opposing Devastator. The ships can move between short, medium, and long range. Attack cards may be played at the appropriate range. Devastators may also launch Fighter Squads or Nanotech Swarms which continue to fight the opposing ship until they are destroyed.

When you inflict damage on an opposing ship, your opponent must discard a number of cards equal to the damage inflicted. When all of your opponent’s cards are in his Destroyed discard pile, you have eliminated him from the game.

36094.name: Devastators 2500
36094.description:
“The larger Interstellar warships go by many categorical names: Dreadnaughts, Battlers, Star Cruisers, and of course, Devastators. Each player controls a Devastator, or ship, represented by his deck. Play pits Devastator vs Devastator. Run out your opponents deck to destroy his ship.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards. The object of the game is to destroy the opposing Devastator. When you damage the opposing ship, your opponent must discard a number of cards equal to the damage inflicted. When all of your opponent’s cards are in his Destroyed pile, you have won the game.

Re-implemented by:
Devastators 3000

36095.name: Deadlock
36095.description:
A science-fiction game of planetary colonization, military conquest, and diplomacy. The game is played on a 5x5 grid. Terrain is randomly generated each game.

“Board/Card/Record Keeping game for 2-4+ players. Based on the 1996 Sci-Fi PC Game ‘Deadlock: Planetary Conquest.’ Races: Each player picks as their identity one of the 7 available races - Human, ChCh-t, Uva Mosk, Tarth, Re’Lu, Maug, Cyth. Victory: You win by occupying all territories on the map.”

The detailed turn sequence has 20 phases: Upkeep Phase, Labor Phase, Event Phase, Population Phase, Morale Phase, Taxation Phase, Rebellion Phase, Resource Phase, Diplomacy Phase, Trade Phase, Black Market Phase, Build Phase, Production Phase, Ability Phase, Transport Phase, Attack Phase, Plane Return Phase, Colonization Phase, Research Phase, and End Phase.

36096.name: Daimyo
36096.description:
“Medieval Japanese Warfare theme. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Victory: You win if you kill your opponents Daiyamo.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units, which come in ten types: Daimyo, Ashigaru Spearmen, Bushi Gunners, Bushi Spear Cavalry, Warrior Monks, Samurai Swordsmen, Samurai Horse Archers, Samurai Archers, Samurai Heavy Cavalry and Samurai Naginata. Both players start with an identical assortment of sixteen units which may set up as they desire on their back two rows of the board.

A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36097.name: Cold War Era
36097.description:
“Simulation of Soviet-American Relations during the Cold War Era (1945-1991). One player takes the role of America (USA). The other player is the Soviets (USSR). Players use Power Tokens to keep track of their Scores in the Areas of Power. Use poker Chips, coins, counters, etc. to represent PT. There are 5 Areas of Power: Military, Economic, Social, Espionage, and Territorial.”

“There are 3 ways to achieve Victory. General Victory: If your scores in the 5 AOP are greater than your opponent’s for two consecutive turns, you win. Power Victory: If your scores in any 3 AOP (except Espionage) are double or greater than your opponent’s for two consecutive turns, you win. Crisis Victory: If your opponent goes to zero (or less) in any AOP (except Espionage) you win.”

The game provides three setups: Equal, Random, and Historical. Card play generates changes in the AOP levels of the players.

36098.name: Classic Dungeon Crawl
36098.description:
“This simple card and dice miniature game is based off of the very original Dungeons and Dragons, back in the days of Chainmail and the Classic Dungeons and Dragons boxed set. If the game rules seem a bit simple and occasionally clumsy, they are supposed to be. That was the charm of the ‘Proto-D&D’ fantasy miniature wargaming.”

“This game can be played with 1 to 3 players. For solo play, this is a simple solitaire adventure system for ‘proto-D&D’ fantasy miniature battles. For two to three players, it becomes a competition to survive (be warned that multiplayer games can get very lengthy; it’s best to take this game in sessions like you would a modern D&D adventure, breaking between dungeon levels.)”

Each dungeon level uses a different deck of cards composed of the types of monsters found on that level of the dungeon. On each turn the player draws the top card from the deck for the dungeon level his character is on and fights the monster. If the player’s character is killed, the player is out of the game. If the monster is defeated, the player receives gold and experience points. A certain number of experience points is required to advance to the lower dungeon levels.

36099.name: Baron Munchausen
36099.description:
“Card game for Aristocratic Adventurers and other Fantasists. Players use melds of cards to retell the tales of the Baron & score points. Victory: The first player to score 100 points wins.”

The deck contains seven types of cards, inspired by elements of the Munchausen stories: Dramatic Mood Swings, Extraordinary Companion, Romantic Interlude, Brush with Death, Exotic Location, Preposterous Escape, and Envious Enemy. In addition, there are two Jokers and two Fools.

Unusual twists to the game include the “Side Bets and Wagers” phase in which players may wager over the truth of “any claim whatsoever”, with the loser required to give a card (or other agreed upon stake) to the winner of the wager. In addition, there is the “Ungentlemanly Conduct Rule”, which allows you to steal a random card from an opponent’s hand once per game.

36100.name: Baroque Masters
36100.description:
“Each player is an Architect in Rome during the Baroque Era 1600's. Players try to increase their own reputation at the expense of their Rivals. Victory: When the deck runs out a second time, the player with the most Reputation Points (RP) wins.”

The game is played with a custom deck of cards which come in five types: Patrons, Commissions, Quality, Actions, and Events. The players score points by playing melds consisting of a Patron Card and a Commission Card. In addition, any number of Quality cards may be added to the meld to increase the number of Reputation Points received for the meld.

36101.name: Baseball Outs
36101.description:
A baseball game played using dice and cards and incorporating the general rules of baseball.

The players draw two cards each turn and may hold a hand of up to seven cards. After the card draw, two six-sided dice are rolled to determine the result of each “at bat.” The die roll result may be modified by the play of Hit, Batter, Effect, and Pitch Cards. After the batter’s fate is determined, and the base runners advanced (if necessary), Fielding Cards may be played. The deck also includes Automatic Result cards which may be played in lieu of the batting roll before the dice are rolled.

36102.name: Batman
36102.description:
A card game inspired by the characters and events of the Batman comics and movies.

“One Player is Batman, the other is the Nemesis player. The Batman player uses the Batman Deck. The Nemesis player has 3 decks: the Villains Deck, Location Deck, and Action Deck. Object: The first player to accumulate ten Victory points wins.”

36103.name: Battle Bots
36103.description:
“The concept behind this game is the programming of warrior robots that fight each other. Each robot comes equipped with 4 sensors, a rotating ablative shield and a turret mounted laser. Inspired by Robo Rally.”

The game is played on a square grid, the size of which depends on the number of players. Each player has two pieces, a robot model and a shield marker (the latter denotes the current facing of the robot’s shield). The players also use identical decks of 22 programming cards. These cards are gradually discarded as a player’s robot takes damage.

36104.description:
“A two player game of Fantasy battles using Dice to represent individual units. Object: Play continues until one side routs or is utterly destroyed. Dice: Dice are also referred to as troops and units.”

Each type of die represents a different type of Unit in the game. A four-sided die is a General Unit (Leader or Warlord), a six-sided die is an Infantry Unit, an eight-sided die is an Archer Unit, a ten-sided die is a Cavalry Unit, a twelve-sided die is a Mage Unit, and a twenty-sided die is a Monster Unit. The players start with an equal number of dice, but each may choose a different assortment (with each player being limited to one type of monster).

Each turn begins with the players rolling all of their dice. Combat is then resolved by first consulting the Monsters followed, in sequence, by combat separate resolution for Leaders, Mages, Cavalry, Archers, and Infantry.
36104.name: Battle Dice

36105.name: Battle for the Universe
36105.description:
“Millions of years in the future, admits a universe dying a cold, premature death, mankind has overcome great challenges. They have conquered and outlived every alien race. They have overthrown a millennial reign of a cruel quasi-immortal tyrant. They have occupied all the remaining habitable galaxies of the Universe. But their greatest challenge is now themselves. The Human species has evolved into two different peoples: the Morlocks and the Eloi. And now they battle each other to determine which of them shall be masters of the universe.”

“One player plays the space fleets of the Eloi. The Eloi are a gentle, yet determined people, under the vigilant care of their Empress. They seek to liberate the six galaxies from the cruel Morlocks.
