One player plays the space fleets of the Morlock Empire. The Morlocks are a fierce and technologically advance people. The only way they wish to serve the Eloi, is on their dinner tables. Each player uses an identical deck of cards. Six sided dice will also be required.”

“Goal: To win, one player must possess all six of the inhabitable galaxies of the Universe. To capture (or recapture) a galaxy card, one must win a battle by destroying all of the opponent’s ships.”

36106.name: Battle Magic
36106.description:
A game of large scale fantasy warfare. The object of the game is to destroy all of your opponent’s castles. The standard game involves wars between Human empires, each of has five castle counters. Variant counter mixes are given for the Dwarf empire, Orc empire, and Undead empire, which have counter mixes with four to seven castles. However, each player starts with only one castle, one army, and one ship on the board.

The game uses a deck of cards which serves several functions. Move Cards are used to initiate movement. Sword and Magic Cards are used to aid units in combat. Gold Cards are used to recruit new units.

36108.name: Battle of New Orleans
36108.description:
“The British with superior numbers charge into a shower of cannon shot and sniper fire while attempting to install Ladders over the Rodriguez canal. Their goal is to overrun the American defenders, however their leadership and troop Strength is being decimated. Can the British complete the task before it is too late? Victory: The Americans win if all British units are destroyed. The British win if all American units are overrun. Otherwise the British score is the number of American units that were overrun. The British player with the highest score wins.”

In this abstract wargame, set during the War of 1812, the British units are represented by six-sided dice. The face-up number shows the strength of each unit. The units are moved down a twenty space track. Moving dice off the end of the track helps reduce the strength of the American forces by removing cards from the American Troop deck. The British win when all American Troop cards have been eliminated.

The game may be played in three different ways: solitaire, two-player (American versus British), or multiplayer (two or more players play the British competing for high score).

36109.name: Battle of the Atlantic
36109.description:
“War at Sea 1939 – 1943. German High Seas Fleet vs the British Royal Navy. Victory: Be the first to win 3 hands. There are 3 card types: Tactics, Tonnage, and Technology. Each card has an individual point value.”

The winner of a hand is determined by the point values of the cards played by each player. The game lasts five turns, corresponding to the years 1939 to 1943.

36110.name: Battle Royale
36110.description:
An abstract battle game played on Strategic and Tactical Boards. The object of the game is to capture the opponent’s castle.

The Tactical Board is a 6x6 grid containing six randomly placed terrain obstacles which block movement. The Strategic Board is a 7x7 grid. The corner squares and center square on the Strategic Board are Towns, and the center square in each player’s back row is a Castle.

Both players start with six Armies on the strategic map, one located in the Castle and the other five in the surrounding squares. When opposing Armies occupy the same space on the Strategic Board, they are immediately moved to the Tactical Board for battle. A partition is placed in the center of the Tactical Board so that the battling forces may be set up in secret. The Tactical Battle concludes when one side has no pieces left, or if no pieces can move, or if no further captures can be made by either side, or if ten turns elapse without a capture being made.

Players earn gold from occupied towns. Gold may be used to recruit (purchase) new units.

36111.name: BattleTech Skirmish
36111.description:
A tactical boardgame set in the Battletech Universe. Each player controls a group of Battlemechs. The object of the game is to capture the opposing leader.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. The game provides specifications for forty-two different Battlemechs. The statistics provided include hit points, movement, jump capability, and damage inflicted at close, medium and long range.

Each player assembles a force of Battlemechs with up to 50 hit points. Movement and combat are governed by the cards. The players draw hands of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36112.name: Beach Head
36112.description:
“Solo dice game simulating the actions on a small section of the Normandy Beach landings in WWII. Objective: The game ends when the Allies remove all German Bunkers and Trenches. Removed may mean ‘cleared of troops’ in the case of Bunkers and trenches or ‘Punching through gaps’ for Traps, wire, walls, mine-fields, & ditches. Scoring: Keep track of Allied Infantry casualties. A lower score is a better one.”

The game is played with paper, pencils, and six-sided dice. The rules include a game variation for Omaha Beach.

36113.name: Bellum Astralis
36113.description:
“Space empires against each other and the bug threat.”

The map is randomly constructed, drawn on a piece of paper. Each player selects a starting world for his empire. A random number of worlds (1-6) are infected by Bug units, which reproduce and spread to other worlds. The players each start with one frigate, one freighter, ten troops, six food units, and six machinery units. Agricultural worlds provide one food unit per turn. Industrial worlds convert one food unit to one machinery unit each turn.

The winner is the player who has the most victory points after ten turns. Victory points are awarded at the end of each turn based on the types of worlds controlled, for each cruiser owned, and for having the longest trade route.

36114.name: Berserker
36114.description:
Inspired by Fred Saberhagen's Berserker series.

“Human fleet vs a Berserker Ship. Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: Destroy the opposing fleet.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. The Human Fleet player has a force of sixteen ships against the single Berserker ship. Each ship is rated for hit points, speed, and attack range. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36115.name: BESM
36115.description:
An anime themed card game. The name stands for “Big Eyes, Small Mouth”, a description reflecting the appearance of anime characters. The players compete to be the first to capture 200+ Force Points worth of Foes. Foes are captured by forming teams of Friend cards to battle and capture the Foes.

The game is played with two decks - the Foes Deck and the Friends deck.

The Foes Deck contains a total of 31 Foes (Devils, Ghosts, Ninjas, etc.) and Minions (such as Cat Girls, Lesser Demons, and the Inept Recurring Nemesis.)

The Friends Deck contains over 120 cards in 16 different types: Event, Character, Companion, Fight, Vehicle, Mech, Magic, Power, Tech, Attribute, Shape, Enhancer, Flaw, Gun, Sword, and Location.

36116.name: Biker Brawl
36116.description:
Rival motorcycle gangs face off in a duel to the death.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Each player has eight bikers in his gang. Bikers come in three different types: Leaders, Veterans, and Gang Members. Each gang has an assortment of motorcycles, guns, knives, and tool boxes to distribute among the members. The game is driven by a custom card deck. The players draw hands of cards from the deck, and card play determines when units may move or attack.

36117.name: Biomechanoids
36117.description:
A card game based on the fantasy creations of artist H.R. Giger.

“Players raise armies of Biomechanoids to destroy each other with. Victory: Reduce your opponent to zero hits. Each player starts with 20 hits.”

The game is played using a deck of over 120 cards, which come in seven types: Location, Biomechanoid, Feature, Artifact, Action, Reaction, and Destiny.

36118.name: Bionicle Skirmish
36118.description:
This is an abstract, skirmish-level combat with Bionicle theme. Each figure (unit) represents a single Bionicle. One player controls the good Toa Nuva. The other player controls the evil Rahkshi. You win if you destroy all opposing Bionicles.

Bionicle Skirmish is played on an 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combatants. Both teams consist of seven unique Bionicles, and each Bionicle has a special power. However, the Rahkshi player only starts with six units on the board. The seventh evil unit, the powerful Makuta, does not appear unless the other six Rahkshi units are all eliminated.

The cards are central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, defend, or use special powers.

36119.name: Birthright Conquest
36119.description: “Card game for 2 players. Set in the AD&D Birthright Campaign Setting. One player controls the Armies of Good. The other player controls the Armies of Evil. Victory: Destroy all your opponents. To destroy an opponent, you must: Reduce your opponents Realm deck to zero cards. Then eliminate all his Realms in play.”

36120.name: Blade
36120.description:
“Solo Card game based on the Blade Movies/Comics. Blade is a Daywalker Vampire Slayer.”

The game is played with two decks, the Aid Deck and the Foe Deck. The latter contains various Foes and Locations. Blade starts with twenty Blood Points and five Aid Cards. He must battle a series of Foes at a number of different locations.

“Victory: You win if at the beginning of Foe Phase all Foe cards in the game are in the Foe discard pile. You lose if Blade is reduced to zero or less Blood Points.”

36121.name: Blown Away
36121.description:
“18th Century Naval Combat. Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Sink the opposing Flagship.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. Each player starts with an identical assortment of ships: one Flagship, two Ships of the Line, two Frigates, and three Sloops. The game uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from the common deck, and card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36122.name: Blue vs Gray Combined Arms
36122.description: A Civil War themed diceless strategy game played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Each player builds a custom army of sixteen units composed of a General and an assortment of five other regiment sized units: Cavalry, Infantry, Riflemen, Artillery, and Mortar. Optional rules are provided for terrain (hills and forts), elite units, experienced units, and reinforcements. The object of the game is to occupy all of the Forts or destroy the enemy General.

36123.name: Border Keep
36123.description: “Each player controls a small town in a fantasy setting. Every turn players build structures and hire heroes to defend their town. Some cards are used to send monsters and disasters to destroy your opponent’s towns. The Deck: The deck has 75 cards. These will have to be constructed before play is possible. Object: Have the most defenders and structures at the end of the game. Each defender and structure is worth 1 victory point. The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck. In a multiplayer game, the game ends if all but one player’s town is destroyed.”

36124.name: Box Cars
36124.description:
“Train-themed Dice-and-scoring game for one or more players. Use 10 sided dice. 10 dice are required.”

A player starts his turn by rolling 10 dice. The player then has the option to re-roll up to eight of the dice, then up to six, then up to four, and finally re-rolling up to two. The resulting combination of numbers are scored using the names of train cars. A full game consists of five turns. The highest scoring player wins.

36125.name: British Sudan
36125.description: “2 player card game around the Mahdist uprising in the Sudan 1885-1898. One player is the Anglo-Egyptians. The other player is the Mhadists. Decks: There are two unique decks, one for each player. Regions: There are five region cards: Egypt, Northern (Military) Sudan, Southern Sudan, Western Sudan, and Eastern Sudan. Victory: A player automatically wins if he ever controls all 5 regions at the same time. The player who controls the most regions at the end of turn 9 is the winner.”

36126.name: Buccaneers
36126.description:
“Boarding Action between two Pirate ships. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Captain.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the pirates, which come in five types: Captains, First Mates, Bullyboys, Sailors, and Sharpshots. The game uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36127.description: A boarding party of Space Marines has been tasked to assault the USS Argos and eliminate the alien "Bugs" which have overrun the ship. At your disposal are six Marines, a Lieutenant, Tech, Medic, and two Gunners. Your goal is to clear the four central areas of the ship. Your level of victory will be reduced if the Lieutenant or Tech get hit.
36127.name: Bug Hunt

36128.name: Bug Out
36128.description:
A strategy game with a bug theme.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Twenty-eight Bug counters are placed on all of the squares around the edges of the board. There are four each of seven types of Bugs: Bee, Ant, Ladybug, Grass Hopper, Beetle, Spider, and Dragon Fly. Each type of Bug moves differently. The players take turns moving uncontrolled Bugs. When a player moves a Bug, one of the player’s Control Markers is placed on it. If you line up three Bugs under your control in a row (orthogonal, not diagonal), then you score one point and your control makers are removed from the Bugs. The winner is the first player to accumulate seven points.

36129.name: Bujutso
36129.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Oriental Martial Arts Theme. Abstract skirmish level combat. Man to Man fighting. Victory: You win if you kill your opponents Leader.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the men, which come in three types: Leaders, Bodyguards, and Followers. The players also choose they type of Warrior Band they are playing: Samurai, Ninja, Monk or Bushi.

Each type of Warrior Band uses a custom deck of cards which is central to the play of the game. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

36130.name: Cabal
36130.description:
A game based on the role-playing game Mage: The Ascension.

Each player controls a Cabal of Mages. A player keeps two hands of cards simultaneously: a Foe Hand and a Spell Hand.

To win the game, you must meet all of the following conditions: One or more of your Mages must ascend to the 10th Level (Oracle); you must establish a Chantry (control one or more Nodes); and all Foes in your Territory must be at 5th level or less.

The game components are: Four card decks (Mage, Spell, Attribute, and Foe Decks), Tokens (to track Wounds, Experience, Talismans, Transformations, and Conversions), ten and six-sided dice, and a pencil and paper.

36131.name: Cannonade
36131.description:
“Napoleonic era tactical combat simulation. Watch out for grapeshot.”

Each player is given 100 points to construct a force from the following types of units: Infantry (1 point), Cavalry (1.5 points), Cannon (10 points), Officer (3 points), and Baggage (supply wagons, 2 points). Each player also receives a Flag unit “for games of capture the Flag.” The players must also construct their own map of the battlefieldt using four abstracted terrain types: Clear, Covered, Fortified, and Impassable.

The object of the game is to obtain the most Victory Points, which are awarded in varying amounts for killing or capturing units.

36132.name: Calcala
36132.description:
“2-4 Player Mancala Variant using a square 36 pit board. Capture the Most stones by the end of the Game. The Game ends when there are only 6 or less stones remaining on the board. The board is composed of 36 Pits (spaces) laid out in a 6 by 6 Grid. Use glass beads or whatever (seeds, nuts, pebbles) for Pieces. Players share a common set of Stones. Each player has his own pile (cup) where he keeps the Stones he has captured. Setup: Place 2 Stones in each Pit. The least gracious player goes first.”

The rules provide four alternatives to the standard setup: Short Game (1 Stone in each pit), Long Game (3 Stones in each pit), Double Dutch (3 Stones in every other pit), and Half Dutch (2 Stones in every other pit).

36133.name: Car Chase
36133.description:
“Simulates a car chase between the Law and a Fugitive. Winning: The Fugitive wins if the Law does not catch him at the end of 7 turns.”

The game uses a custom deck with seven types of cards: Investigation, Fugitive, Chase, Escape, Capture, and Location. At the start of each turn the players fill their hands up to ten cards, with the option to discard and redraw up to five. The remainder of the turn consists of up to three phases of card play - the Search Phase, Chase Phase, and Escape Phase.

The turn ends with any Phase that the Law player loses. The Law player must win a series of all three Phases to capture the Fugitive and win the game.

36134.name: Caravan
36134.description:
“Players control Arabian caravans going back and forth across the deserts, acting as Middlemen between Europe and the Orient.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any similar 8x8 grid. Row 1 on the board represents Europe, row 8 is the Orient, and rows 2 through 7 are designated Middle Eastern rows. Each Middle Eastern row receives one Oasis and one Quicksand marker on different random spaces. Four pawns are used – one for each player to represent their caravans, one to represent Bandits, and one to represent a Sandstorm. An eight-sided die is required for play.

A Players chooses to start in Europe or the Orient. Players draw cards to obtain goods or soldiers, and to collect movement cards. Players then play movement cards to transport their goods to the opposite end of the board where they may be sold for Gold. The first player to accumulate fifty Gold is the winner.

36135.name: Carny
36135.description:
“Players are setting up their Game Booths at the Fair. Card game for 2+ players. Carnival: A cooperative business arrangement between independent showmen, ride owners and concessionaires to present outdoor amusement for the public. Carny or Carney: Someone who works in a carnival. The term is also applied to the carnival itself. Game Length: Each turn = 1 day. Before play, players decide on the duration of the Fair from 5 to 20 days. Winning: The Player with the most money at the end of the Fair wins.”

Discard and draw cards to attempt to form melds. Earn money by playing up to two melds each turn. Increase the value of your melds by playing good Event Cards. Decrease the value of your opponent’s melds by adding bad Neighbor or bad Event cards to them.

36136.name: Castle Keep
36136.description: A game of medieval conquest. The object is to be the first player to control seven castles on the map. The players must construct their own hex mapsheet containing twelve castles. Five terrain types are used to create the map: clear, forest, mountain, river, and sea. Each player starts the game in control of three castles and three armies. The game uses a custom deck of cards which are played to resolve battles.

36137.name: Castle Siege
36137.description: The Defenders have sixteen units: four Knights, four Archers, four Cannons, and four Boiling Oil Cauldrons. The Attackers are assaulting with twenty-eight units: eight Knights, four Archers, four Cannons, four Sappers, four Battering Rams, and four Siege Towers. The Attackers must breach the castle walls to take the fight to the Defenders. A six-sided die is used to resolve combat, and to determine how many units a player may move.

36138.name: Cat & Mouse
36138.description:
“Two player card game representing terrorist activity and government countermeasures. One player represents US Security. The other player is the Terrorists.”

Each player uses a unique deck of cards. The U.S. player attempts to play combos which force the Terrorist player to discard cards. The Terrorist player is attempting to play a meld, which represents a successful attack and ends the game. The U.S. player wins if the Terrorist player runs out of cards without playing a meld. The U.S. player can also win by guessing the Terrorist player’s meld as it is played but before the cards are revealed, which represents the attack being preempted.

36139.name: Cave Wars
36139.description: The game is played on a chessboard or 8x8 grid representing a subterranean setting. The map is randomly generated each game by filling the board with sixty-four terrain tiles. Each player starts in control of one Lair. The object of the game is to occupy all eight Lairs on the board. The players earn Gold to build an army of cave creatures, such as Dwarves, Orcs, Cave Trolls, Kobolds, Troglodytes, and Gnomes. The players keep a hand of Event Cards which can be played to affect movement and combat.

36140.name: Cellular
36140.description:
“Card game using concepts from general biology. The deck includes 85 cards. Object: Accumulate the most points at the end of the game, or over several games.”

Each player is dealt a hand of eight cards from which they attempt to play special combinations. Over forty combinations are defined, such as Photosynthesis (using the cards Chloroplast, Chlorophyll, Light Reactions, Dark Reactions), Sexual Reproduction (using Gametes, Fertilization, Zygote), and Mitosis (with Mitosis, Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, Telophase.)

One point is scored for each card in the combination. The game ends once there are no cards left in the deck or any time a player has no cards left in his hand.

36141.name: Celtic Saga
36141.description:
“Players take the role of Celtic Warrior Heroes in ancient Ireland. Players compete to make their Hero the most famous of all. The winner will be sung about by bards for generations and his exploits will be written of in the Book of Kells.”

The game comes in two versions, Ulster and Fionn. A separate deck of custom cards is used for each version.

The players accumulate cards to score points in four categories: Blessings, Fortune, Victory, and Prophecy. The player who has accumulated the most points in the most categories after seven turns wins the game.

36142.name: Celtic Skirmish
36142.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Minor Battle between two Celtic War Bands. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill the opposing Chieftain.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the men, which come in three types: Chieftans, Champions, and Warriors. A custom deck of cards plays a central role in the game. The players draw a hand of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36143.name: Celtic Warbands
36143.description: “Theme: Continental Celtic Intertribal Warfare circa Fifth Century BC. Poker type mechanics. Victory: The first player to win 5 turns wins the battle. Background: Each player controls a band of rival Celtic Warriors. Each game represents a battle between these opposed Tribes. Each hand represents a Champion: His weapons, traits, etc. Each turn represents a duel between 2 Champions. The winner of the turn takes the severed head of the losing Champion.”

36144.name: Challenge of the Superfriends
36144.description:
Based on the 1978 season of the Superfriends TV cartoon.

One player controls the Superfriends (Justice League), the other player controls the Legion of Doom. The game uses a custom card deck for each player. Each deck includes Character Cards and Plot Cards.

To win a hand a player must play Plot and Character cards having a higher total Power Value than the cards played by the opposing player. The first player to win a total of seven hands wins the game.

36145.name: Champion Chess
36145.description:
A two player card game with a chess theme. One player plays Black, the other plays White. Each player has an identical custom deck of 52 cards, composed of Noble cards and Aid cards. The object of the game is to capture your opponent’s King.

The game consists of a series of challenges, where the player’s simultaneously choose one Noble card from their hands and lay it face up on the table. The players can then add up to six Aid cards from their hands, played face down, to assist the Noble. All cards are then turned face up to see which side has the highest combined Move, Attack, and/or Defend ratings. The losing Noble is captured. In the case of a tie, both Nobles are captured.

36146.description:
"Solo Dice & Record Keeping Game. Simulation of the Charge of the Light Brigade, the final phase of battle of Balaclava in 1854."

"Materials: Six sided Dice, Paper, Pencil. Your Men: The player controls a British cavalry group of 12 men known as a ‘Troop.’ All men are mounted on horses. All men are armed with a sword. One of the men is the Captain, the leader of the troop. Another man is the Trumpeter. The other 10 men are referred to as riders. There are 3 types of Troops: Dragoons, Hussars, and Lancers. Pick which type you want your troop to be."

The player must move his twelve men down a 20 space track, all the while facing the constant threat of musket and cannon fire. At the end of the track the men engage in Melee combat with the Russian Gun Battery. After five turns of Melee, the Troop must move back to the start of the 20 space track. The player scores two points for every man that makes it back alive and one point for every Russian killed during the Melee.
36146.name: Charge of the Light Brigade

36147.name: Chinese Rummy
36147.description:
“Chinese symbolism theme with rummy/poker mechanics. The Deck: Players share a common deck. The deck contains 27 cards. There are 5 Suites each with 5 cards numbered 1-5.”

The five suits are Elements, Blessings, Virtues, Directions, and Beasts for Sacrifice. In addition there is one Ying and one Yang card. The first player to play a five card meld wins the games.

There are three types of melds: flush, straight (all from different suits), and five of a kind. The Yin card serves as a wild card for a flush, the Yang cards serves as a wild card for a five of a kind.

36148.description:
“These battles take place in China in the 1920's. Anarchy and Lawlessness reign. Now is the time for enterprising individuals to gain power.” The object of the game is to kill the opposing Warlord or capture his stronghold.

Each player begins with one stronghold, one warlord, three peasants, two thugs, and one bodyguard. The players collect income from their stronghold and villages. Income is used to recruit additional men, weapons, and vehicles. Units which may be recruited include Trusted Lieutenants, Machine Guns, Artillery Pieces, Armored Vehicles, and armed Boats.
36148.name: Chinese Warlords

36149.name: Chronos
36149.description:
“Chronos is a game of Time exploration for 3-5 players, inspired by Lloyd Krassner's Time Line.”

The game is built on a Time Map made up of square tiles. Each tile is named for an era (Prehistory, Renaissance, Near Future, etc.) and has three values marked on showing its position in the overall timeline, the number of victory points gained for control of the era, and how resistant the era is to control. Every player has three units, a Leader, Agent, and Explorer. Leaders and Agents are used to gain control of uncontrolled eras. The game ends when a player has 22 victory points. A shorter Easy Game scenario is also included.

36150.name: City of Heroes Skirmish
36150.description:
“Battle between Superheroes & Villains. Takes place in the City of Heroes Universe. Each figure (unit) represents a single Hero or Villain. Victory: Destroy all opposing Units.”

A non-collectable game based on the City of Heroes CCG. The game is played on a 12x12 hex map. The Hero player picks six Heroes and the Villain player picks one Villain group. The players draw hands of cards from a shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

36151.name: Civil War Poker
36151.description: A poker flavored betting game played with a custom deck having five suits. Each suit has ten cards. There are also two wild cards in the deck. The winning hands, from lowest to highest, are a pair (suited), two pairs, three of a kind, full house, four of a kind, straight, and five of a kind. Ties are broken by comparing suits: Infantry beats Cavalry, Cavalry beats Artillery, Artillery beats Infantry, Generals beat all other suites.

36152.name: Classic Space Opera
36152.description:
“Explore intergalactic space and fight the Slish (enemy aliens), and pay off your ship!”

A simple card based space adventure game inspired by White Buffalo’s Starfaring. Each player starts with a Scoutship with nine crewmembers and a captain. The players travel through space, battling aliens and facing hazards, seeking to discover planets. Send down a landing party to make contact with aliens and battle them. Encounters and events are generated by the card decks. The Imperial Scout Service pays the players for various discoveries and for destroying Slish spacecraft.

36153.name: Clinical Studies
36153.description:
“Players are rival medical scientists trying to out-publish each other. Objective: The player to accumulate the most Publisher Points at the end of the game wins. The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck.”

There are six kinds of cards in the deck: Study, Methodology, Statistics, References, Journal, Flaw, and Research. To publish a study, a player must play a Study Card and a Journal Card plus one or more Methodology, Statistics, and References Cards. The player receives one publisher point for each card played when publishing a study.

36154.name: Colonial Florida
36154.description:
“Historical period: Florida 1513 (Ponce de Leon) – 1821 (American posession). Each player represents one colonial power: Spanish, British, or French. The Deck: Players share the Enhancement deck. The deck contains two types of cards: Income Cards & Combatants.”

These cards are played onto an abstract map of Florida, a ring of 36 spaces marked with the names of geographic features and locations of settlements. The players gain income by controlling settlements.

The first player to accumulate 50 Gold is the winner.

36155.name: Colonials
36155.description: “Each player controls a coastal colonial settlement in 17-18th Century North America. Each player’s colony is from an opposing European group including: The English, French, Spanish, and Dutch. Victory: The first player to accumulate 30 Population, 20 Gold, 10 Resources, and 3 Town Improvements wins. If you ever reach zero population, you automatically lose.”

36156.name: City States
36156.description:
“War and politics in ancient Greece. Six and Ten sided dice are required. The Board: Use a map of the Aegean circa 430 B.C. Divide the map into spaces, either hexagonal or irregular shaped. Make sure to include cities that existed at the time. Victory: Control the most city states at the end of 36 turns.”

Each player starts with a home city, three leaders, ten gold, and six city traits. A city also receives two armies, two rowers, and two fleets, unless the city is landlocked in which case it just receives four armies. Each player also starts with five cards. The cards can be used as an aid in areas such as battle, diplomacy, and movement.

36157.name: Combat Dice
36157.description:
“Get ready to throw lots of dice around. The game simulates two opposing fantasy warriors locked in deadly combat.”

Combat results are generated by rolling several six-sided dice every turn. Each number corresponds to one of six different attributes: 1=Attack, 2=Dodge, 3=Damage, 4=Armor, 5=Initiative, 6=Maneuver. The player’s value in each attribute is determined by the number of times that number was rolled on the turn. The respective results of the warriors are compared to determine if an attack hit, if damage was caused, and if dice can be rerolled. Advanced rules add specific injury results, weapons, armor, skills, magic, and ranged combat.

36158.name: Company Commander
36158.description:
“WWII Simulation of Combat between two infantry companies. One player represents the Americans, the other is the Germans. The Decks: The game uses 3 decks. Players share a common Tactics Deck. Each player has their own unique Squad Deck. Victory: The first player to destroy or rout 10 enemy squads or units wins. If after 2 turns, you ever have units at all three fronts and your opponent only has units at one or none, you automatically win.”

The game includes rules for recon, suppression fire, assault, flanking, and armored vehicles.

36159.name: Condottieri Captains
36159.description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Italy 1200-1550. Each player is an Italian City State. Victory: Play ends after everyone has had 10 turns. The Player with the most Provinces wins. If Provinces are tied, the tied player with the most Ducats wins. Defeat: If you are ever reduced to zero Provinces, you automatically lose. Whoever conquers your last Province gets all of your cards and Ducats."

Each player plays one of eight Italian city states and starts with five provinces, represented by five tokens. The provinces (tokens) must be captured through card play battles.

36160.name: Conquistador
36160.description: “You (Cortez) control a band of Conquistadors seeking Gold in the New World. Conquistador Points: You start with 20 Conquistador Points (CP) (1 Point = 25 Men). If you are ever reduced to zero CP you automatically lose. The Deck: There is one deck. There are 2 main card types: Conquistador cards and Indian cards. Conquistador card types include: Expedition, Diplomacy, War, and Disease. Indian card types include: Aztecs, Tribes, and Settlements. Scoring: The game Ends when there are no cards left in the Deck. At the end of the game put all your Ally cards into the Gold Pile. Your score = the total point value of the cards in the Gold Pile.”

36161.name: Corps of Discovery
36161.description:
“Thomas Jefferson bought (bargain-price) Louisiana from the French in 1803. This purchase more than doubled the size of the United States. Meriwether Lewis & William Clarke were chosen by Jefferson to Explore this vast, unknown region. They assembled a group of Soldiers, hunters, boatmen, and slaves (40-50 men) known as the Corps of Discovery. They set off from St Louis in 1804. They Traveled as far as the Pacific. The Expedition lasted two and a half years. They returned safely after mapping large areas, finding new plants and Animals and meeting many new Indian Tribes.”

The players compete to acquire the most discovery cards by making sets of four and seven cards. Solo victory conditions are also included.

36162.name: Conquest of Canaan
36162.description:
“Canaan circa 1300 – 1100 BC. Each player represents one Nation vying for control of Canaan (Palestine.) The land of Canaan is represented by a pool of 20 City Tokens. Tokens (of a different color) are also used to keep track of Armies. Each Army Token a player owns generates 1 Force in the Conquest Phase. Each Army Token roughly represents 1,000 men. Victory: At the end of 20 turns, the player with the most City Tokens wins.”

Each player plays one of seven nations of the ancient Middle East. Each nation has a special ability. Through card play the players fight battles to gain control of Canaan.

This is a free game which requires paper, pencil, and your own created cards, maps, tokens, and dice. Directions for play are on the Warp Spawn Games website. Create your own game and place the images with the link below!

36163.name: Cosmosis
36163.description: A card game themed around celestial bodies. The object of the game is to be the first player to score 100 points playing combos. The game uses a custom card deck that includes six kinds of cards: Active Galaxy, Galaxy, Stellar Object, Main Sequence Star (MSS), Planet, and Special cards. There are a number of different combo hands that may be played. You score one point for each card in your combo.

36164.name: Crecy
36164.description: “Simulation of the Battle of Crecy 1346 (Hundred Years War.) Card Game for 2 players. One player represents the English, the other the French. Victory: The game lasts 16 Turns (Charges/Hands.) To win the battle the French must win 4 hands in a row, or win the last Hand by double the Force of the English, otherwise the English win.” Each side has its own custom deck of cards.

36165.name: Crimea
36165.description:
“Simplistic Simulation of the Crimean War 1854-56. One player is the Russians. The other player is the Allies (Anglo-French). Victory: The first player to win 7 Battles is the winner. If you have ever won 3 more battles than your opponent, you win. If a player is reduced to zero Troop Tokens he loses.”

The players draw cards from a common deck. Reinforcement Cards add to your Troop Tokens. Epidemic Cards are played to eliminate your opponent’s Troop Tokens. Battles are fought with Attack, Defense, and Blunder cards.

36166.name: Cross & Crown
36166.description:
“Players are Royal Dukes using political, religious and military influence to gain the most economic control of a disputed region.”

The game is played on a 10x10 hex map with 20 Settlements marked on the board. Players draw counters out of a cup and place them on empty squares. The counters are affiliated with one or two types of influence: Religious, Political, and Military. Control of Settlements is established by having the most counters of one type surrounding a settlement. The game ends when there are no empty spaces left on the board.

36167.name: Crusades
36167.description: “Players lead rival bands of Crusaders in their efforts to conquer Palestine 1096-1271. Christendom: Players units never attack each others’ units or settlements. They can only attack Turkish troops and Turkish controlled settlements. The Turks are not controlled by any player. Crusader nationalities include: German, French, English, Byzantine. Victory: Be the player with the most Victory Points at the end of Turn 15. Victory Points are obtained by controlling settlements.”

36168.name: Custer's Last Stand
36168.description:
“American West: Indians vs Soldiers. Each figure represents a group of cavalry soldiers or Indian braves. Victory: Destroy your enemies completely.”

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. The middle four squares are each occupied by one Soldier. All edge spaces each contain one Indian. A custom deck of cards is key to the game play. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36169.name: Custom Space Fury
36169.description:
“Quick & Dirty Tactical Space Fighter Combat Rules. Special rules for pilots: 10 Skills, Panic, Quirks, Special maneuvers. Very easy ship construction system. Supplies: A space hex map is required. Use painted miniatures or chits to represent ships. 10 and 6 sided dice are used.”

The game includes rules for Morale, Cloaking, Detection, and Critical Damage. Pilot Experience rules provide for Experience Points, Skills, Quirks, and Panic.

36170.name: Cyberiad
36170.description:
Cyberiad: Exploits of the Constructors is a card game based on the book The Cyberiad by Stanislaw Lem.

“Setting: A medieval universe populated by sentient robots. The constructors are prolific inventors with almost god-like powers. Each player takes the role of a Constructor, trying to gain the Most fame. Victory: The player with the most Fame points at the end of the game wins. Any player that accumulates 50 or more Fame points automatically wins. Any player that accumulates 20 or more Trouble points automatically loses. Game End: The game ends when one player has claimed 7 Sally cards or the Deck is empty when a player starts his turn.”

36171.name: D&D Miniatures Quick Rules
36171.description:
A highly simplified set of miniatures rules for use with D&D Miniatures, or suitable for use with most other fantasy miniatures. The designer states he created these rules so he could play with his six year old son.

“Designer Notes: These rules are sufficient for a 6 year old. He has fun just fiddling with the figures (so do I). It should be obvious to determine unit size and type. Medium & Large units have the same size base but I consider anything larger than human as Large. Big & Huge units have the same size base but some units are noticeably larger. For now we treat Clerics as Fighters & Mages as Shooters.”

36172.name: Da Vinci Poker
36172.description:
“Poker variant with a Leonardo da Vinci theme. Players share a Unique 52 card deck. There are 5 Suites: Art, Earth Science, Humanities, Engineering, Life Science. Each suite represents a field of knowledge that Leonardo contributed to. The 5 Suites comprise 50 of the cards. There are 2 Additional 'Renaissance Man' cards that act as Wild cards.”

Each card is marked with four pieces of information: Suit, Rank (from 1 to 10), Name and Details (the latter two provide unique Da Vinci flavor for each card).

36173.name: Dark Ages Empires
36173.description:
“Wargame for 2-8+ players. Europe Early 6th Century after the Fall of the Western Roman Empire. Victory: The player to conquer the most other nations by the end of the Game is the winner. Time Scale: Each turn is 5 years. The game starts in 500 AD and ends in 600 AD.”

Each player leads one of 20 kingdoms of early Europe. The remaining territories are neutral. If all of a player’s armies are eliminated by another player, his kingdom is conquered but the player can continue by taking control of one of the neutral kingdoms.

36174.name: Dark Sun Adventures

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

36174.description: A boardgame set in the AD&D Dark Sun campaign setting. Each player controls a party of six adventurers attempting to acquire and return with the Rod of Divining. The map is a 40 space track. The first party to reach the end of the track obtains the Rod of Divining. That party must then return the Rod to the start space to win. However, if an opposing party is able to defeat the party carrying the Rod, then the victorious party obtains the Rod and may return it to the start space to win the game.

36175.name: Dark Sun Skirmish

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

36175.description:
A boardgame set in the AD&D Dark Sun campaign setting. Each player randomly selects a party of eight characters. To win the game a player must destroy all enemy characters. The characters come in several races, such as Halfling, Dwarf, Human, Elf, and Half Giant.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid (a chessboard would suffice.) Miniatures or counters are used to represent the characters. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36176.name: Death Racers
36176.description:
“Mad Max style post-apocalyptic gang-warfare road combat.”

Each player starts with a random assortment of six vehicles, each of which has a random piece of equipment (mostly weaponry of some sort) which can be used a random number of times as determined by the roll of a six-sided die. The road is a track 100 spaces long with randomly distributed obstacles.

One player is designated as the Slow Gang, the other player is designated as the Fast Gang. The Slow Gang vehicles start at one end of the track and must try to reach the other end. The Fast Gang player may place his vehicles on any space on the track. The Slow Gang player wins by getting at least three vehicles to the opposite end of the track, otherwise the Fast Gang player wins.

36177.name: Deity
36177.description:
“Players assume the roles of certain lesser Demigods. Each demigod begins with a small band of worshipers. Gain power by building temples and helping your population grow. Crush your enemy’s populations with acts of god and the armies of the faithful. The last remaining immortal is the one true Deity. Objective: Destroy all of your opponent armies, populations, and temples.”

The game is played on a 10x10 or 12x12 hex map filled with terrain counters placed by random draw at the start of each game. A deck of Miracle Cards provides the players with the ability to either benefit their own forces or harm enemy forces. The number of Miracle Cards a player receives each turn depends on the number of temples controlled by the player.

36178.name: Denizens of the Deep
36178.description:
“When Atlantis sunk into the sea, the only survivors who could still occupy the city were the Mermen and the Tritons. Even then, the inhabitants of Atlantis were still plagued with numerous enemies. The evil and powerful Sea Witch has summoned all the enemies of Atlantis together to destroy the city. The Sea King and his faithful allies stand ready to repel the monstrous horde.”

One player plays the Sea King, the other player plays the Sea Witch. The object of the game is to kill the opposing commander. Each side has a different allocation of undersea forces, including Mermen, Whales, Giant Sea Turtles, Sharks, Eels, Rays, and Pirhana. Some units are able to use magic. Each unit is rated for Attack Dice, Defense, Movement, and a Hide Factor. The game is played on a hex map filled with deep and shallow water terrain types.

36179.name: Desert Storm Solitaire
36179.description:
“Solitaire card game with Desert Storm Theme.”

There are two decks in the game: The Coalition Forces Deck and The Iraqi Deck. The player controls the Coalition Forces. Points are earned for eliminating Iraqi units. Points are lost for losing Coalition units. The game ends when the Iraqi deck is exhausted.

36180.name: Desperate Housewives Card Game
36180.description:
“Each player takes the role of a ‘Desperate Housewife.’ Players compete to get the best Husbands, Houses, Jobs, Kids, etc. Victory: The Player with the Highest Total Card Score at the end of the game wins. Add up the score for each card you have in play. Game End: The Game ends when the player who draws the last card in the deck ends his turn.”

The custom deck includes over eighty cards, including cards representing housewives, houses, men, children, events and ‘modifier’ cards which either improve or degrade other cards.

36181.name: Destiny
36181.description: A fantasy adventure game where the players compete to be the first to obtain five treasures. Each player takes on the role of a randomly drawn character, ranging from a Thief or Jester to a King or Emperor. Each hand the players compete to win a treasure by trying to play cards which will have the highest combined Destiny total.

36182.name: Diamond Traders
36182.description: The players share a common 60 card deck. The deck is made up of five suits, each of which has twelve cards. The object is to have the largest point score after four turns. Points are scored by revealing “Stone” combos containing one card from each of the five suits: cut, color, clarity, karat, and kind. Five variants are included, mostly intended to produce longer or shorter games.

36183.name: Disciple Lords
36183.description: “Card game for 2-4 players. Based on the Disciples Computer Strategy Games. Players Share one Common Deck. Each player has a unique Race Deck. The common deck has 6 types of cards: Locations, Advances, Items, Potions, Events, Treasure. Each race deck contains 5 types of cards: Leaders, Summons, Followers, Spells, Buildings. Each player keeps 2 hands: 1 Common deck hand & 1 Race deck hand. Major Victory: Capture all of your opponents’ Cities. Minor Victory: The game ends when any players Race deck runs out. The player controlling the most cities at that point wins.”

36184.name: Dodeca
36184.description: A game played on a 10×10 grid using dice as pieces. The game requires ten four-sided dice, four six-sided dice, four eight-sided dice, and two ten-sided dice (the Dodecas.) The object of the game is to capture both of your opponent’s Dodecas. Before the dice are placed on the board, they are rolled and placed with the resulting numbers showing. A player can take one of two actions each turn: move a die a number of spaces equal to the number on its top face (each type of die moves differently) and change the number showing on the die by +/- one, or reroll a die to reset its face-up number.

36185.name: Dodge Ball
36185.description: A game played on an 8x8 grid or chessboard. Each player needs six pawns or checkers, etc., to represent the dodge ball team members. These are placed on the back rows of the board at the start of the game. Skills are rolled for each of the players (there are six: Dodge, Fast, Aim, Catch, Strong, and Quick). One piece on each side is designated the Team Captain, who receives a second skill. The game is played using a custom deck of cards. The cards are played to move a player or throw the ball.

36186.name: Dogma the Board Game
36186.description: A game based on the Kevin Smith movie Dogma. The object of the game is to be the first player to get your pawn to the Church Gates (the end space on the board.) One player takes the role of the Last Scion, the other player takes the role of the fallen angels Loki and Bartleby. The board is fifty spaces long. Each space relates to people or incidents from the movie. The spaces are marked as one of the following types: Joke Space, Good Space, Evil Space, Test Space, Distraction Space, Help Spaces, and Bad Spaces. Each type of space has a different effect.

36187.name: Doubloons & Dragoons
36187.description:
“Players take the role of Merchant Princes in control of their own city state. Thru conquest and trade they try to outdo their opponents in the quest for Gold & Glory. Object: Conquer all Cities on the map.”

The game is played on a hex map with 25 cities, some landlocked and some on the ocean. The game includes rules for the Black Plague, favor of the church, trading, taxation, production or military and trade units, spy missions, and diplomacy.

36188.name: Dracula's Castle
36188.description:
“One side is Dracula and his minions. The other side is the Vampire Hunter and his assistants. Action takes place inside Castle Dracula. Victory: Completely eliminate all of your opponent’s pawns.”

The Vampire player starts with Dracula and three lesser vampires. The Vampire Hunters are a team consisting of the lead vampire hunter and four assistants. Movement is simultaneous based on secret written orders. Each side has a custom deck of cards that are used to extend movement and for attack and defense.

36189.description: Variant rules adding card play to Chinese Checkers. The variant uses a deck of 40 custom cards. There are three types of cards in the deck: Move Cards, Destiny Cards, and Special Cards. Move Cards are used to make one or more pieces move in ways they don’t normally move. Destiny Cards affect other cards, the deck, your hand, or your opponent’s hand of cards. Special Cards have various “special” effects.
36189.name: Dragon Checkers

36191.name: Dredd
36191.description:
“Based on the comic series Judge Dredd. Players share 3 common decks: Judge Deck, Criminal Deck, Event Deck. Each deck has its own discard. A player will keep cards from all 3 decks in his hand. Victory: Be the first player to accumulate 100 Prestige Points. Prestige Points are gained by apprehending Criminals.”

“Teams: Each player controls a team of up to 4 Characters. Most characters will be Judges. Stats: Each Character will have 2 Stats: Fight & Investigate. A Stat will usually have a value between 0 and 4. Characters will also have one or more Traits such as: Judge, Psychic, Alien, etc.”

36192.name: Drop Troops
36192.description:
“Futuristic Tactical Miniatures Ruleset. Each player controls a squad of heavily armed Drop Troopers (Space Marines.) For use with typical Space Marine pewter and plastic figs.”

The equipment provided for in the rules includes light and heavy weapons systems, grenades, pistols, hand to hand weapons, power suit systems, and armor. The rules also cover Detection, Ammo depletion, Medical Care, Repairs, Morale, Psionic Abilities, and Neohuman Races.

36193.name: Duel of Iron
36193.description: "Civil War era tactical combat simulation. Players each control one or more Ironclads. The rules are for the basic scenario, in which one player controls the Confederate Merrimac, and one player controls the Union Monitor. Use a hex map. Indicate which spaces are land and which are water. Indicate whether water spaces are shallow or deep. Six, eight, and ten sided dice are needed. Use cardboard counters (chits) to represent the ships."

36194.name: Dungeon Keeper
36194.description:
“Based on the Computer Game of the same name. Each player controls their own Dungeon, which they try to build up, in spite of a continuing onslaught of Heroes.”

Using a Room Deck and Spell Deck, amass a collection of Rooms, Creatures, Gold, Mana, and dead Heroes – but don’t allow your Dungeon Keeper to be killed or your Heart Room to be captured, as these lead to instant defeat.

36195.name: Jacked Card Racing
36195.description:
JACKED is a deck-based trading card racing game, with decks available for different types of tracks, vehicles and modifiers that you can collect and trade with your friends.

With all kinds of JACKED TRACKS and JACKED VEHICLES to choose from, and lots of ways to modify and play them.

36196.name: Dungeon Master
36196.description:
“Dungeon Crawl Card game. One Player is the Dungeon Master. The other player is the Party Player. Each player has his own unique deck. The Party Player must create an adventuring party. A party starts with 6 members (Heroes). Pick 10 cards from the Character Deck. Discard 4 and keep 6.”

The Dungeon Master wins the game if all of the Heroes are killed. The Party Player wins the game if the party gains Treasures worth 50 points or more.

36197.name: Durable Goods
36197.description: “Economics Game. Players buy raw materials, manufacture products, and then sell them. Each player starts with $50 and no raw materials or products. Raw Materials Deck: The decks consist of 80 cards or chits. The deck contains 20 each of the following raw materials: Wood, Plastic, Metal, Fabric. Manufactured Goods Deck: Also called Durable Goods. Use chits or cards to represent the following manufactured goods: Houses, Furniture, Cars, Appliances, Clothing. Objective: Be the first player to accumulate $500.”

36198.name: Earth Defense Force
36198.description:
“Takes place in the Star Blazers Universe. Pick your Fleet: Earth Defense Force, Gamillon Empire, White Comet Empire. Abstract skirmish level Ship combat. Each figure represents a single Ship (unit). Victory: You win if you Destroy the opposing Flagship.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the ships. Each fleet has five types of ships. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw their hands from a common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

36199.name: East Front West Front
36199.description: “Card game for 2 players simulating the conflict in Europe in the Second World War. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies. Each player has his own unique deck. Fronts: There are three fronts: The East Front, the West Front, the Mediterranean Front. Each front is represented by 4 Tokens. (There are 4 East, 4 West, & 4 Med. Tokens) Victory: If the Allied player controls all 4 tokens in any one front he wins. To win, the German player must control all 4 tokens in both the East and West Fronts. If the Germans do not win by the end of 1945, they automatically lose.”

36200.name: Egypt
36200.description:
“Card game simulating 3000 years of rule by the Pharaohs of ancient Egypt.” There are seven kinds of cards in the deck. Each turn the players attempt to play the highest scoring meld to establish control of Egypt. A meld is two or more cards of the same type. The player who controls Egypt may then play additional melds from his hand to gain tribute points.

“The game ends after 10 turns. Each turn represents 300 years. If the deck runs out before the 10th turn, shuffle the cards and keep playing. Victory: The player with the most accumulated tribute points at the end of the game is the winner.”

36201.name: Empires
36201.description:
“Short rules for a quick play civilization like boardgame.”

Two or more players begin the game with one city and ten counters representing the population and military force. A standard deck of cards is used. A certain type of card, or combination of cards, must be played to perform certain actions in the game. The descriptions of the combinations include: Migration, Merchant, Combat, Apostle, Abundance, Exploration, War, Exodus, Colonization, Crusade, and Foundation.

The object of the game is to control more than half of the provinces on the map. A player who is eliminated may return as a foreign invader, starting with one city and six counters on the outer ring of provinces.

36202.name: Evolved
36202.description:
“It took 3.5 billion years to make this game. Winning: The player with the most species at the end of the game wins.”

A game of evolution. Each player starts with a single species. The game is played on a 6x6 grid composed of three kinds of spaces: Land, Open Water, and Islands. The board is also divided into three types of zones: Arctic, Tropical, and Temperate. The game lasts for sixteen turns, with each turn representing a different Geologic Era, Period, or Epoch, from the Archean to the Quaternary.

36203.name: Exorcist
36203.description: “Card Game for 2 players. One player is the Exorcist. The other player is the Demon. The Demon has taken possession of a young Innocent. The Exorcist is trying to purge the Demon. Each player has a unique deck. Each player gets 50 Soul Tokens. Victory: The first player to win all the Soul Tokens is the winner.”

36204.name: Fabulous Thunderbirds
36204.description:
A game based on the Thunderbirds television show.

The players travel from their Secret Bases to respond to various emergencies determined by card draw. Each emergency requires a certain assortment of vehicles to resolve. All players have an identical assortment of vehicles to work with: "Thunderbird 1" through "Thunderbird 5", and "FAB 1."

The object of the game is to make more rescues that your opponents.

36205.name: Fairy Circle Ring
36205.description:
“It is Spring Equinox in the Sylvan woods. The little people, also referred to as Fairies, or Fey have gathered to celebrate. After feasting, storytelling, gossiping, and singing they gather around the Fairy circle ring to play a game they call the Dance of Eights. The fairies dance in groups until they finally form a perfect circle of eight dancers. The winners get laurel leaves and an extra helping of Pixie dust on their elderberries.”

The winner is the first player to build a “ring”, or hand of eight cards, composed of a specified mix of dancers according to their gender, size, alignment, and Earth element.

36206.name: Fall of France
36206.description:
“Solo Card Game. 10 May 1940. The player takes the role of the Germans invading the Western Democracies. There are two decks: The Allied Deck and the German Deck.”

To advance your campaign, you must play melds with a higher Force total than the Allied Cards on the table.

“Objective: You win if you run the Allied deck out of cards. The Allied forces collapse and you conquer France in 6 weeks. If you ever accumulate 7 delay tokens, the Allies have stopped you and you must fight a long war against France.”

36207.name: Fall of the Aztecs
36207.description:
“Two player set piece strategic game. One player controls the Aztecs. The other player controls the Spaniards and their allies: The Totonac, Tlascalans, Texcocoans, and Cholula. Victory Conditions: The Spaniards must capture the Aztec leader Cuahtemoc. The Aztecs must capture the Spanish leader Cortez.”

The battle is fought on a hex map depicting the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan. Each Aztec unit represents 10,000 Indians. Each Spanish unit represents 100 Spaniards.

36208.name: Fallujah
36208.description:
“You control a US Marine Company on Patrol in Fallujah.”

The game uses a custom deck of sixty cards. There are ten different kinds of cards in the deck: Insurgent Tactics, Insurgents, Positions, Explosives, American Tactics, Infantry, Armor, Support , Recon, and Disarm.

The player’s score is based on how many casualties are suffered by the player's Company versus the number inflicted on the enemy.

36209.name: Fantasy Fight Club
36209.description:
“Combat between 2 opposing fantasy warbands. Game progresses in 2 stages: Recruit Stage. Battle Stage.”

In the Recruit Stage, the players create their warbands by receiving a random selection of ten warriors to which they must assign their random assortments of weapons and armor cards.

The game is played with five decks of cards -- the Warrior, Weapon, Armor, Spell and Fight Decks.

36210.name: Fantasy Fighters
36210.description:
“Card game of Fantasy combat.”

The game is played with a custom deck of fifty cards. Combat consists of playing card combinations which represent specific attacks the fighters can carry out. The fighters also have combinations which can be played in defense. The game comes with statistics for three sample fighters.

36211.name: Fantasy Heroes
36211.description:
The game is played with two decks – the Territory Deck and the Battle Deck.

The Territory Deck has fifteen cards, three each of five types: Castles, Mountains, Towers, Forests, and Swamps. The Battle Deck has sixty cards, which come in four different types: Heroes, Minions, Artifacts, and Spells. The Heroes and Minions are each associated with a specific type of Territory.

The object of the game is to control all of the Territory Cards.

36212.name: Fantasy Skirmish
36212.description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two Fantasy Armies. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single hero, monster, or unit. Victory: You win if you kill all opposing units with Leadership Skill.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the combat units. Each player purchases sixteen units using an equal amount of points. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards from this shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

36213.name: Farmers
36213.description:
A card game of competitive farming.

Resource Cards represent crops and animals on the farm. Points are scored by having Resource Cards in play when a matching Market Card is played by any player. In addition, there are Setback Cards which cause all players with certain Resource Cards in play to lose points. The game ends when one or more players reach twenty or more points.

36214.name: Farmers of Ur
36214.description: “Players each control a settlement in ancient Mesopotamia. Players are trying to be the first to develop their village into a full-fledged city. This Honor belongs to the first player to build a Ziggurat. Tokens represent the manpower and materials needed to build the Ziggurats. Victory: The first player to accumulate 60 Tokens is the winner. If two players both go over 60 in the same turn, the player with the highest total number of Tokens wins.”

36215.name: Fiefs
36215.description:
“Medieval Dukes contest for gold and lands. Object: The player with the most gold at the end of the game wins. Board: The board is a 3x3 grid. The Central square is the Palace. The 8 Surrounding squares are the lesser Fiefs. Deck: Players use a common deck. The deck contains 78 cards.”

Each player starts with one corner Fief, six Gold, three Bishops, four Nobles, five Knights, and a hand of seven cards from a custom card deck. The players obtain gold by controlling squares on the board – one gold for each Fief and two gold for the Palace.

36216.name: Kagemucca
36216.description:
The funniest cow war in the world... the Mucca Games party game!

Each player receives a set of cows (Elite, Rookie, Cow Waste "Vaccacca") and place the cards face up. Each player studies the placement of the other players' cards, then the cards are covered.
The current player attacks another players' card with one of his cards: if they are of the same kind, nothing happens; elsewhere, the battle is resolved using the "Rock-Papers-Scissors" rules: the Elite beats the Rookie, the Rookie beats the Waste, the Waste beats the Elite.
The winner takes the losing card as a point; the winning card cannot be attacked during the next round (current player passes clockwise).

Kagemucca was introduced in Mucca Games in 2006 by the author, Valerio Cassiano, who managed the First World Kagemucca (Preview) Tournament.

Valerio Cassiano passed away a few months later.

Kagemucca was produced by Mucca Games and daVinci Games in 2008, with the help of the Cassiano family, and of many Mucca Games friends.

The cows on the cards are illustrated by:

Simone Pacioni (the Original Ones!), Gianpaolo Derossi, Emanuela Matricardi, DRMA (Domenico, Roberta, Matteo, Andrea ) Di Giorgio, Daniele Barletta, Alberto Di Giorgio, Luigi Ferrini, Alberto Bontempi, Martina Mealli, Paolo Vallerga, Marco Giammetti, Giordano "Giò" Segatta, Martino Palladini.

36217.name: DECiMiX
36217.description:
DECiMiX is a game where the aim is to be the player scoring the most points at the end when all tiles have been placed.
There is a pool of tiles in the centre of the table, and each player has a hand of 5 tiles. Each time a tile is placed, the player draws back up from the pool.
On each turn a player can play as many of their 5 tiles as they feel is advantageous - each tile played must adjoin a piece already on the board, and the numbers in each triangle of the tiles must add up to a total of 10.
Scores are made for completing squares of 4 pieces, and should be added to the players score tally as soon as the square is completed.

203184.name: Animals expansion (mini fan expansion for Dominion)

36218.description:
(from the back of the box:)

"You are a monarch, like your parents before you, a ruler of a small pleasant kingdom of rivers and evergreens. Unlike your parents, however, you have hopes and dreams! You want a bigger and more pleasant kingdom, with more rivers and a wider variety of trees. You want a Dominion! In all directions lie fiefs, freeholds, and feodums. All are small bits of land, controlled by petty lords and verging on anarchy. You will bring civilization to these people, uniting them under your banner.

But wait! It must be something in the air; several other monarchs have had the exact same idea. You must race to get as much of the unclaimed land as possible, fending them off along the way. To do this you will hire minions, construct buildings, spruce up your castle, and fill the coffers of your treasury. Your parents wouldn't be proud, but your grandparents, on your mother's side, would be delighted."


In Dominion, each player starts with an identical, very small deck of cards. In the center of the table is a selection of other cards the players can "buy" as they can afford them. Through their selection of cards to buy, and how they play their hands as they draw them, the players construct their deck on the fly, striving for the most efficient path to the precious victory points by game end.

Dominion is not a CCG, but the play of the game is similar to the construction and play of a CCG deck. The game comes with 500 cards. You select 10 of the 25 Kingdom card types to include in any given play—leading to immense variety.


Part of the Dominion series.

Integrates with:

Dominion: Intrigue
36218.name: Dominion

36219.description:
Tenaha is a somewhat unique pattern matching and hand management domino game that requires 5 sets of Double Six dominoes, a draw bag and a set of poker chips (you need around 20 of the same color/pattern per player) to play.

The poker chips are used to mark completed sets (i.e. squares) and keep score.
36219.name: Tenaha

36220.name: Königswahl
36220.description:
In Königswahl, each player takes the role of a medieval dynasty in the Holy Roman Empire between 1000 and 1600. Players start as bondsman and attempt to ascent ranks, with the goal to obtain ministry positions at the court of the kaiser. Each ministry equals one vote. The objective of the game is to gain enough votes to assign the new emperor after the old kaiser died.

By managing workers, building new buildings, trading with cities, raising taxes, diplomacy and using political influence, cultural development, population growth, and military actions, each player tries to reach specific conditions which qualify him/her for either secular or religious ascension. Moreover, each player has to guarantee the continuous existence of her/his dynasty by getting offspring and marrying offspring with the offspring of other players.

In each round, every player plans ahead 5 actions which, in most of the cases, can be played simultaneously. Seven different kinds of actions are possible (diplomacy/intrigue; get influence cards; income/trading; build; development; expansion; action upgrade), each of which can be improved up to five levels (except for "action upgrade").
The population size determines the number of workers a player commands. Workers are necessary for military expansion, operating buildings, trading with cities etc.

36221.name: America's History: Multicultural Contributions to America – Modern Age to Contemporary Period
36221.description: This is primarily a trivia game. Players move around the board answering questions. The player with the most correctly answered questions wins. A set time period is used to determine when a particular game is completed.

36222.name: Code-Cracker
36222.description:
Each player has a rack with a row of six disks on top and a row of six disks on the bottom. Each disk has numbers from 0 to 6. The top row is adjusted by the players to form their 'secret codes' while the bottom is used to deduce the code of the opponent.

The codes are cracked by drawing question cards, which must be truthfully answered by the opponent. The questions are in the form of simple mathematics involving the dials on the secret code, such as "what is the sum of the third and sixth figures" or "multiple the second figure by the fourth".

By collecting the information in this manner, the players try to deduce the secret code of their opponent, and the first to do so wins!

36223.name: The Pickle Game
36223.description: Ever wonder just how many kinds of pickles there are? Of course you haven't! But we did… Here players strategically change the ingredients in jars of pickle brine, each trying to achieve the correct ratio of ingredients to complete different pickle recipes.

36224.name: Mad Scientist: Frankenbuilder
36224.description: Play a Mad Scientist student, racing to animate your first monster! Send your unreliable assistants (Agor, Egor, Igor, Ogor, Ugor, or Ygor) to collect diverse body-parts from different graveyards, with the hope that you can cobble something together from the mis-matched parts.

36225.name: Playbook Football
36225.description:
The closest you can get to football without wearing shoulder pads!
Playbook Football appeals to anyone who enjoys football, from the armchair quarterback to the dedicated season ticket holder. It is easy to learn, fast to play, and has all of the tactical depth of football. Constructed out of high-quality, all-wood components, Playbook Football is a beautiful piece of home décor as well as an engrossing game of strategy and luck.

With 10 years of football statistics incorporated into the play cards this is the most accurate football board game ever brought to market. Players feel the excitement as the plays they call carry them down the field to victory or deny the opposing team critical yardage. From basic calls to fancy plays like the Blitz and Screen Pass, if you can do it in football, you can do it in Playbook Football!

Players complete a full game in less than an hour. Every game is different, keeping players going all night long. Expansion packs with custom plays are planned for release in 2009, letting players build their own playbook and team. Want to see how your team stacks up to anyone else in the league? Grab a friend after the game and find out!

36226.name: Mad Scientist: Lab Rats
36226.description: Players are Mad Scientist students chasing escaped, mutated lab rats throughout the Mad Scientist university. Each rat has developed different powers while being a lab rat (psychic rats, genius rats, giant rats, mutant rats, etc.), and they can put up one heck of a fight!

36227.name: Mad Scientist: Final Exam
36227.description: As Mad Scientist students, players collect, trade, and assemble hands of cards as they go through their crazy final exams. Hand ranks change during the round, causing players to bet on the winning hand and change strategies mid-game at the whim of capricious teachers.

36228.description: Players play colorful taxi chariot drivers in ancient Rome, picking up and transporting famous (and infamous) passengers, and competing to collect the most fares by the end of the day.
36228.name: Roman Taxi

151282.name: Toboggans of Doom: Promo Tile Set

36229.description:
The feel of the wind on your face, the sight of the finish line just over the next snow bank…and the elation of rocket-jumping over evil trees while being chased by a phalanx of chainsaw-wielding snowmen! It’s the wild challenge of extreme downhill sledding against a hill of crazy, zany, fun obstacles in Toboggans of Doom!

Compete to acquire the coolest, most effective upgrades to survive the various obstacles that cover the hill. Can you use gadget legs to get over your ex-girlfriend? Will you power up for orbital re-entry to plow through the Viking Opera? Will the other players laugh as they fly over your broken toboggan…only to fall into a volcanic fissure?

Toboggans of Doom has a unique bidding system where each player uses a collection of dice to bid on different upgrades. Designed for fantastic two person play, up to four players can join in just by adding additional dice to the game, beautifully illustrated by CCG artist Jason Engle. Toboggans of Doom plays simple and fast, with three rounds of building toboggans, hurtling down the hill, and sledding for your life!
36229.name: Toboggans of Doom

36230.name: Dogfight
36230.description:
Eight unique solid metal die-cast Classic WWII airplanes stored inside a solid wood game board.
Strategic without being difficult, you can set up and teach the game in only a few minutes.
Each airplane is sculpted and hand painted based on the specifications and markings of the classic European theatre airplanes of the Second World War.

The skies over Europe saw some of the most brutal aerial battles of the Second World War. Dogfight is a wood and metal strategy board game that recreates these battles, letting players fight for control of the sky.

Games can be completed in as little as 15 minutes; making this an ideal game for strategy gamers without little free time on their hands. Also the high quality components make this an ideal display piece. This game will easily grace the coffee tables of the most demanding executive gamers.

Lovingly-crafted in wood and metal, the pieces are all beautiful as well as functional. The wooden board will withstand many hours of play, and the die-cast, hand-painted metal planes are custom molded to be the most realistic, historically accurate planes available. With a wingspan of more than 1.5 inches (38mm), each plane is a work of art … even as you shoot it down.

36231.name: Rorschach
36231.description:
Play personality detective as you unravel the inner workings of your friends’ minds. They have secrets, and so do you. Maybe there’s a maverick inside you; can your friends predict what you will do? Or will you keep them guessing while you expose their inner selves to the world?

In every round of Rorschach, each player picks an inkblot that answers a question asked on a card. To win the game, you must pick the same inkblot as each other player at least once, and you must be the only one to pick an inkblot at least once. Can you figure out whether the other players are giving honest answers? Or are they trying to pick the same inkblot they think you will choose? Can you throw them off your scent so as to make a unique selection for an extra point? Subterfuge abounds in this game of skill, timing, and intrigue.

Rorschach contains 100 new and unique inkblot cards that are large, widely varied, and graphically stunning. The question deck covers a broad range of topics, keeping play fresh every time. One expansion is planned for the game, adding an even larger selection of questions and blots, and additional questions and inkblots will be available to print from www.bucephalus.biz.

36232.name: Top Ten: The Bill of Rights
36232.description:
A patriotic party game where players represent different secret societies trying to get the rights that they believe in reflected in the final Bill of Rights by voting among themselves. The winner is the player to whom the final list closest reflects the goals of his/her society.

Part of the Top Ten series. See also The Ten Commandments.

36233.name: The Ten Commandments
36233.description:
Recreate the Ten Commandments with your friends! Each player has a set of goals for the final version of the Ten Commandments, and they debate and vote among themselves to get the Commandments that they want in the final ten.

Part of the Top Ten series. See also Top Ten: The Bill of Rights.

36234.name: Michelangelo
36234.description: In Michelangelo, you will be one of these assistants, splitting your time between Michelangelo’s workshop and the political beehive of Renaissance Italy. You will earn money and points by helping Michelangelo, as well as making connections in some of the most powerful and influential families of the world.

boardgamehonor.24510: 2013 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee

36235.description:
Levy. Maneuver. Conquer.

The Duke is a dynamic, tile-based strategy game with an old-world, feudal theme, high-quality wooden playing pieces, and an innovative game mechanism in its double-sided tiles. Each side represents a different posture – often considered to be defensive or offensive – and demonstrates exactly what the piece can do within the turn. At the end of a move (or after the use of a special ability), the tile is flipped to its other side, displaying a new offensive or defensive posture.

Each posture conveys different options for maneuver and attack.
