The Resource Cards include Villages, Towns, Mines, Castles, Cities, Knights, Ships, and Trade Routes. These efforts can be aided by Leader Cards and Advancement Cards. However, Invasion, Disaster, and Event Cards can hinder a player's efforts.

The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck. The player with the most gold wins.

36446.name: Kung Fusion
36446.description:
A card game of martial arts combat. The game uses a custom deck containing fifty-six cards, with eight cards for each of seven different types: Punch, Kick, Block, Grab, Move, Zen, and Combo.

The players must roll fighter characters before play. Each fighter has ten hit points and rolls ten times on a series of Maneuver Tables. This results in a list of "moves" the fighter knows and some die roll results can add hit points. Each Maneuver is rated for a cost in cards that must be played to use the move and for damage caused by the move (Attack Maneuvers) or damage negated (Defense Maneuvers).

The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero hit points.

36447.name: Naval Engagement
36447.description:
"Card game for 2 players. Simplistic WWII era Pacific sea battle simulation."

The game is played with a custom deck of sixty cards. There are fifteen different cards, with four copies of each in the deck. Cards are Units, Attack, Defense, or Special. Unit and Attack cards are combined to make attacks to reduce Fleet Points, while Defense cards can negate attacks.

Each player begins with ten Fleet Points. The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero Fleet Points.

36448.name: Ready Aim Fire
36448.description:
"Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare."

The game used three types of cards - Battalion, Commander, and Tactics. The Tactics deck is composed of maneuvers, formations, weapons, incidents, and terrain types. There is a different composition of Battalion and Commander cards given for each of the five nations represented in the game: France, Britain, Austria, Prussia, and Russia. Each player forms a Battalion Deck and selects Commander cards based on the country played.

Cards are played on the table in battlefield positions representing the Left Flank, Left Center, Center, Right Center, and Right Flank positions. The first player to be routed from three of the five forward positions loses. A player may also lose based on morale considerations.

36449.name: Magic Knight Rayearth
36449.description:
A card game based on the manga cartoon series of the same name.

The game uses a custom set of sixty cards reflecting heroines, allies, and villains from the series. Heroines include Fuu Hououji, Hikaru Shidou, and Umi Ryuuzaki. For each heroine there are Heroine cards and Team Up cards.

The allies are Clef and Ferio. Villains include Alcione, Ascot, Caldina, Innova, Lafarga, Mokona, Presea, Princess Emeraude, Zagato. There are Plot and Villain cards for each villain.

The playing area is divided into two sides, one for each player, each consisting of a 3x3 card playing grid. Defending cards are played face down on this grid. The object of the game is to have a card reach one of your opponent's third rows at the same time that you have a card in any position on one of the opponent's other columns.

36450.name: Harry Potters First Year Adventure
36450.description:
"Board game for 2-4 players. Help Harry recover the Sorcerers Stone."

Each player portrays a wizard who has several attributes, skills, and abilities which must be tracked during the course of the game: House Affiliation, Magic skill, Flying skill, Study skill, Chess skill, House Points, Clues, Wealth, Wand Type, Familiar Type, Chocolate Frogs, All Flavor Beans, and Other Possessions.

The playing board is broken into three segments - a straight track representing Dagon Alley, a loop representing Hogwarts, and a second straight track representing the Dungeon. Players move one space per turn on the straight segments and roll a die for movement on the center loop. Each space has a special table or tables that must be rolled on when a player enters the space.

"Victory: The player with the most house points at the end of the game wins. The game ends when someone defeats Voldemort in the last space of the dungeon."

36451.name: Hong Kong Phooey
36451.description:
"Trump taking Card game for 2 or 4 players. Based on the Hanna Barbara Cartoon Hong Kong Phooey. Winning: The player with the lowest score after 4 Rounds wins the game."

The game uses a custom deck of forty cards. There are four suits in the deck: Hong Kong Phooey, Friends, Villains, and Extras. There are ten cards in each suit, numbered 1 through 10.

36452.name: Miami Beach
36452.description:
A card game of city building. The game uses a custom deck of cards. Each card represents one building. Each building has five traits: color, type, size, class, and age.

The players score points by constructing complimentary buildings next to one another. The number of points scored for placing (constructing) a building depends on how many traits it has in common with the immediate neighbor. This ranges from -5 points for zero common traits to 16 points for four traits in common.

"The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck and all possible cards have been played. Winning: The player with the most points at the end of the game wins."

36453.name: My City
36453.description:
A city building board game.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. The playing pieces consist of a set of 24 Zone counters in a different color for each player and a set of 16 Landmark counters. Each Landmark is marked with a Prestige Point value and each Zone counter is marked with an Access Point value.

The Landmarks are randomly placed on the board. The players then take turn placing Zone counters until all the spaces on the board are filled or no player can place a Zone counter. Control of Landmarks is then determined. The player controlling the Landmarks having the highest total Prestige Points wins the game.

36454.name: Master & Commander
36454.description:
"A strategic 2-player simulatiion of naval combat in the Napoleanic era."

The game is played on an 8x8 grid. A chess board may be used. Each player has a set of eight Ship tiles. Ships are divided into four classes, numbered 1 to 4. Ship Class determines attack range, hull strength, and number of masts. Each ship is also rated for six skill types, described as follows in the rules: Seamanship, Gunnery, Command Authority/Discipline, Morale/Courage/Health/Stamina, Marksmanship/Snipers/Muskets, and Boarding/Swashbuckling/Hand-to-Hand Combat/Marines/Crew Size.

"Victory: The player with the most captured ships at the end of the game wins. If tied the player who sunk the most ships wins. The game ends when there are no ships left to capture or sink."

36455.name: Pixie Wars
36455.description:
"Long Ago in the Land of Faerie there was a war between the Sprites and the Pixies. Board & card wargame for 2 players. One player is the Pixies and the other is the Sprites. Each figure represents a single faerie (unit)."

The game is played on a chess board or grid. There are eight different types of terrain: Clearing, Thorns, Water, Great Oak, Thick Growth, Magic Circle, Aerial Roots, and Forest.

Chits or miniatures to represent faeries. Each side has four types of units: King, Mage, Knight, and Warriors. Each unit type is rated for hit points, magic, melee, ranged attack, and poison. The players share a custom deck of cards. Card play is used to determine when units can move, defend, and attack.

"Victory: You win if you kill the opposing King."

36456.name: Quest for the Pirate Chest
36456.description:
Choose to play one of nineteen famous, or infamous, captains - ranging from Sinbad the Sailor to Admiral Horatio to Blackbeard to Jack Sparrow. Each captain has a named ship, crew type, starting port, and special ability that provides an advantage in the game.

The game is played on a circular track divided into twenty-four spaces. Every third space is a port or other special space. All other spaces are open sea.

The object of the game is to find the hidden Pirate Chest and return it to your starting port. To find the Chest you must first gain possession of the Hidden Map and Hidden Key.

36457.name: Santa's Workshop
36457.description: "Card game for 2-4+ players. Each player is one of Santa’s Elves helping to make toys for Christmas. The Elf who makes the most Toys by games end wins. Game End: The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck, and all player’s hands are empty. Victory: The player with the most points worth of cards in his Toy pile at the End of the game wins."

36458.name: Space Swarm
36458.description:
"2-4+ player board & card wargame. Each player controls an Advanced Spacefaring Alien Civilization."

Each Alien Race sends its fleets out to conquer the galaxy. Each Race has six attributes which can change throughout the game: Attack, Defense, Movement, Production, Strategic, and Initiative.

The players share a custom card deck containing two types of cards: Technology and Event. Technology cards give a Race a new ability or an attribute bonus that last for the duration of the game. Event cards represent temporary bonuses and effects.

The game is played on a hex map of space filled with ten "terrain" types: Alien Ruins, Star Cluster, Nebula, Super Nova, Black Hole, Dark Matter, Quasar, Worm Hole, Asteroid Field, and Deep Space. Each type of space has a special effect, except for Deep Space which has no effect.

There are two ways to win the game. Either control all the Star Cluster spaces in play or occupy the most spaces when the deck runs out.

36459.name: Victory at Stalingrad
36459.description:
"Card game for 2 players. Theme: WWII Eastern Front Battle of Stalingrad. One player is the Soviets. The other player is the Germans."

Each player uses a unique deck of cards. There are five suits marked 1 through 10 in each deck. The German suits are Firepower, Objectives, Morale, Tactics, and Forces. The Soviet suits are Defense, Locations, Morale, Tactics, and Forces. The cards depict elements of the historical campaign.

The players attempt to play the highest ranking card combination each hand. "Victory: The German Player must win 3 Hands in a row (Ignore Ties) to win. If the German player has not accomplished this by turn 10 the Soviet player wins."

36460.name: Twelve Brothers
36460.description:
"Card game for 2-6+ players. Fantasy World Setting. King Jaspar the Just is Dying. Only one of his 12 sons can ascend to the Throne. This can only mean that 11 sons must first die."

"Each player is betting on up to 4 of the 12 Brothers to win the Crown. The 4 Brothers that a player is betting on are his Favorites."

"Victory: If one of your Favorites is the last left alive, you win. More than one player can win. It is also possible that all players lose."

36461.name: Warring States Period
36461.description:
"China 475 – 221 BCE. Each player is the king of one of 7 States vying for domination. Card game for 2-7 players."

There are three custom card decks used in the game - the Event Deck, Resource Deck, and Battle Deck. The Resource Deck consists of cards which can be exchanged in combos to raise taxes (Agriculture, Mines, and Cities.) The Resource Deck also contains cards for several types of Generals (Daring, Steadfast, Brilliant, Methodical, and Thoughtful.)

The Battle Deck consists of Strategy and Troop Cards. When battles are fought, the other players may choose to add cards to support the attacker or defender.

"Victory: The first player to control 15 Province Tokens wins the game."

36462.name: Wonder Woman
36462.description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Wonder Woman Theme."

The game is played using a custom card deck. There are ten suits in the deck: Wonder Woman, Ally, Capture, Foe, Info, Plot, Quote, Item, Action, Minion.

"The most feminist player goes first."

The players score points by playing melds of four to ten cards, each of which must come from a different suit.

"Victory: Have the most points when the deck runs out."

36463.name: Mobile Infantry
36463.description:
"Individual Soldier Combat in the world of Ogre/G.E.V."

"Mobile Infantry Soldiers fight as cohesive, Battle suit wearing squads. They combine firepower and area defense measures making them the most effective combat formation in mankinds' long history of warfare. The six-man squad is the norm: 1 Paladin-suit for command and control, 1 Commando-suit for targeting enemy forces and spoofing the enemy’s sensors, and 4 Marauder-suits are the basis of the squad’s firepower."

36464.name: Tron, The Card Game
36464.description:
"Card game for 2 players. The action takes place in the world of Virtual World of Tron."

One player represents Tron and the other plays as the Master Control Program or MCP. Each player uses a separate custom deck of cards.

The Tron deck is made up of six types of cards: Programs (Characters), Skill (used to defeat Games and Security), Escape (used to go Rogue), Activation (used to become Activated), Transport (used to reach the Mesa), and Sub-Routines (various effects).

The MCP deck has four types of cards: Control (required to win the game), Games (used to destroy Programs on the Game Grid), Security (used to destroy Programs off the Game Grid), and Sub-Routines (various effects).

The MCP player wins when all ten Control cards have been downloaded (put into play). Tron wins by Derezzing (destroying) the MCP in Program Delete Phase.

36465.name: Rockets & Rayguns Strategic
36465.description:
A game of full scale war on the planet Mongo. Set in the Flash Gordon universe.

One side controls the forces of Human Hero Flash and his allies, Hawkman Chieftain Voltan and Forest Chieftain Baron. The other player controls the forces of Evil Emperor Ming. Each unit is rated for the following statistics: type, move, initiative, attack, defense, cost, and area of recruitment.

The game is played on a map depicting a major continent on the planet Mongo. There are five regions in the continent. At the start of the game, the Central and Southern regions are under Ming's control while the North, East, and West regions are controlled by the forces of Flash. The regions are further divided into territories, some of which represent Major Cities and some of which are impassable mountains.

The Flash player wins if Ming is killed. Ming wins by killing all of the Rebel Leaders.

36466.name: Rockets & Rayguns Operational
36466.description:
"Rebel troops are attacking Ming’s Palace. Who will carry the day?"

The Rebel forces under the leadership of "Human Hero Flash" are closing in on the palace of the Evil Emperor Ming, ruler of the planet Mongo.

The game is played on a hex map showing the area around Ming's Palace, which is located at the center of the mapsheet. All of the Imperial units start within two hexes of the palace and the Rebel forces start along the map edges.

The Rebels win if Ming is killed. The Imperials win if all of the Rebel Leaders are killed.

36467.name: Lords of Ancient Times
36467.description:
"The game spans over several rounds. Every round each player selects one of the five different roles which will determine a certain action for all players. The player who manages to build the most powerful civilization at the end of the game will be the Lord of Ancient Times."

"Winning the Game: The winner will be the player with most Victory Points at the end of the game." Victory Points are earned by founding cities, discovering advancements, and building wonders.

The designer credits San Juan as the inspiration for this print-and-play civilization building card game.

36468.name: Kill Gwen Stacy
36468.description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Gwen Stacy was Peter Parker’s true love. In order to jack up the sales of their funny books Marvel decided it was a good idea to kill her off. Sales did go up, as did fan outrage. Now heres a chance to redo comic book history but with a twist."

The game uses a custom deck of 52 cards. There are five types of cards: Method, Conspiracy, Location, Save, and Fate.

The players attempt to play melds of cards of the same type.
A player who is unable to play a meld on a turn must roll on the Event table and take the specified action. Once you have three melds in play (one each for Method, Conspiracy, and Location), you may make a die roll to see if you kill Gwen Stacy. If the roll is successful you win the game, otherwise you lose some or all of your melds and the game continues.

36469.name: Piratical
36469.description:
"Players control Pirate ships in search of plunder & adventure. Victory: The first player to accumulate 100 Gold is the winner."

Players move their ships around a circular ring of 48 spaces. The starting space is Port Royal, a safe zone. The other spaces consist of areas at sea or merchant ships. Merchant ships can be plundered for goods, which are exchanged for gold in port. Certain spaces cause turns to be lost, others call for a card draw.

The players face warships, weather, and other hardships. Players can also battle one another when they land on the same space, which can lead to a boarding action.

36470.name: Neolithic Traders
36470.description:
"Players are Stone Age Tribes. Players create and trade objects of value. Victory: The first player with 50 Victory Points is the winner."

The game is played with a custom deck of cards made up of six suits: Weapons, Tools, Food & Textiles, Containers, Jewelry, and Statuettes.

The players score points by playing melds. There are two types of melds, Kits and Hoards. A Kit is a meld of six cards with one card from each suit. A Hoard is a meld of five cards from one suit.

36471.name: Traveler Traders
36471.description:
"A solo card and dice game of trading in the Imperium."

"In this one player game you play the Captain and crew of the FREE TRADER BEOWULF. The Goal is to profit 73 Mega Credits (i.e., 73,000,000 Credits), which is just enough to buy a SUBSIDIZED LINER and become a Merchant Prince. But in the 1350th year of the GALACTIC EMPIRE, this great Utopian civilization of Humanity is far from civilized. Trading in the Spinward Marches Sector, even close to its ducal capital REGINA, can still be dangerous."

Expansion rules allow the game to continue as a Master Trader with a Subsidized Liner attempting to earn another 73 Mega-Credits to build a Mercantile Principality.

36472.name: Nice Weather
36472.description:
In Nice Weather, you and a million tourists travel around Europe chasing, that's right, Nice Weather. Spend your autumns and winters around the Mediterranean, your summers by the Baltic coast and your springs in Central Europe.

Travel by your own railroads or pay the other players to use theirs. Set your ticket prices high to squeeze out profits or low to undercut competitors. If you can't find a cheap train ticket, then you can always go by airplane, in which case you might contribute to global warming. Global warming makes the Southernmost cities unattractive, while new holiday destinations pop up in the far North.

Will you bet on a bright future and invest in ferry lines to the sunny islands of the South? Or will you defy the icy emptiness of the North and then keep prices high to make people fly and tilt the climate in your favor?

Nice Weather is a relatively fast and family-friendly track building game with a foundation of logical thinking paired with prisoner's dilemma-like pricing diplomacy and livened up by random action cards that lets you set hilarious traps. But amidst the easy and fun, the experienced player will inhale a strong breeze of Go as the network struggle scatters among a dozen frontiers that suddenly merge to one final whole, making the player with the most well-oiled micro-macro mental elevator the winner.

Dynamic land prices let you buy up cheap competing lines, allowing for a randomized yet balanced game board; for each game, 6-12 European cities out of 28 are randomly selected, making for up to 36000 different start configurations. Then there is always Essen, and this is where you start the game; in October 2008 to be exact.

36473.name: To Boldly Go
36473.description:
"Card Game for 2+ players. Star Trek theme." The game is played with two custom card decks - the Crew Deck and the Dilemma Deck.

The Crew Deck cards represent crew members, actions and equipment. They are used to solve Dilemmas. Cards have ratings for one or more of the following attributes: Tactics, Science and Negotiation.

The Dilemma Deck cards represent episodes from the first season of Star Trek. Each card lists what levels in the three attributes are needed to solve the Dilemma. Each card also has a Victory Point value.

"Game Ending: The game ends when all Dilemmas have been solved. Victory: The player with the most Victory Points (from solved Dilemmas in his Captains Log) is the winner."

36474.name: Troopers
36474.description:
"A battle between Futuristic Troops."

Each side has sixteen units: eight Troopers, two Tanks, two Aircraft, two Hovercraft, one Artillery, and one Commander. The object of the game is to kill the opposing Commander.

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the units. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the shared deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

36475.name: Pot Leaf The Game
36475.description: Actually a SPIN and Move game. The box says that this game is "The Pot Party Game of Crazy Dares and Hilarious Surprises" The object of the game is to go from the Start to Munchies Land using spin results from a "Do or Dare Spinner". The game box stated that this game is "for fun and is not meant to be played for marijuana. The game pokes fun at those that smoke weed. The game comes with a 12 x 7 game board, a die, a Do a Doobie Dare spinner, 6 game markers and a rule book.

36476.name: Dimension Defender
36476.description:
This is a (relatively) straightforward card battle game that includes a pun (or two). The "fighter" cards that battle are futuristic spaceships called "Multi-dimension Attack Ships" (M*A*S), yeah, you can say "mass." There are cards that destroy an opponent's M*A*S. That card is called, of course, a "Weapon of M*A*S Destruction" (we warned you).

That is a very powerful card, so before you are allowed to play it, you must announce it. If opponent has a Search card, he gets to search some of your cards to try to find it and remove it. The search card is called, of course, a "Search for Weapon of M*A*S Destruction" card. Cute.

The search mechanics are interesting. Players play to win battles and gain Respect Points. When you find Weapons of M*A*S Destruction, you might gain respect (depending on which search card you have). When you don't find Weapons of M*A*S Destruction (depending on the card) you could "lose all your Respect." (ok, no more puns).

Players take turns attacking, choosing between 3 types of attacks. Each card has a "weak spot" on it. During one phase of the game players try to name the weak spot of opponent's M*A*S -- If they do it is destroyed. (These "shots" at opponent's cards are called "long shots"). Battles are usually "2 on 2" with extra "destroy" and "search" cards. Cards are awarded to each player based on rules, mostly "who won the attack?"

There is a Draw Phase, a "Deploy & Destroy phase" a "Long Shot" Phase, and an
"Attack" Phase. After the Draw Phase, each of the 3 remaing phases provides
interesting and different types of action. (See 'more info' below).

2 to 6 players, best with 2 to 5 singles or teams of 2 or 3. 64 cards + instructions.

36477.name: Mega Tank
36477.description:
"Solo Science Fiction Card game with two decks. You control the Mega Tank trying to wipe out the defenders more conventional forces."

The Mega Tank Deck contains cards representing the weapons, defenses, and other aspects of the Mega Tank. The Defence Force Deck contains the numerous units which are opposing the Mega Tank: infantry, bombers, tanks, guns, etc.

If the Mega Tank loses its 40 armor points, each additional point of damage causes a card to be removed from the Mega Tank Deck. If the Mega Tank Deck runs out of cards, the tank is destroyed and the player loses. If all of the Defender cards are discarded to the Casualty Pile before the Mega Tank is destroyed, the player wins.

A game apparently inspired by Ogre.

36478.description:
Gridstones is an elegant, gripping game of strategy and visualization.

Designed by Toronto native Tim W. K. Brown, this critically-acclaimed abstract strategy and puzzle game is quick, fun, easy-to-learn and great for the whole family.

Simply place or remove STONES on or from the GRID to create a match to the cards in your hand - but be careful, your opponents will be trying to match their cards too, and the grid will change with every turn.

So if you’re up to the challenge, grab a friend, or six, and get hooked on this engaging, strategic game of pattern matching.

Grid size versus number of players:

4x4 grid - 2 Players
5x5 grid - 3 or 4 Players
6x6 grid - 5 or more players
36478.name: Gridstones

boardgamefamily.4705: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

36479.name: Spheres of Influence
36479.description:
"Board & card game for 1-5+ players. Pedestrian Glass Bead Game Variant."

The game is played on a 10x10 grid with spaces large enough to contain a single game card. The deck contains over 100 cards specifying historical persons, events, things, places and ideas. Each card has one of fourteen special abilities, such as "draw 2 cards", "place an extra card this turn", or "steal one random card from opponent's hand."

Points are scored by placing cards next to cards with common characteristics. The game ends when the board is completely filled up. The player with the most points wins.

36480.description:
(from GMT website:)

Crown of Roses is a 3-hour block game set during the turbulent years of the Wars of the Roses in 15th Century England. This 35-year long conflict saw the extinction of a large number of noble houses, and would eventually set the house of Tudor upon the throne.

In Crown of Roses, players take on the roles of the dynastic giants - the House of Lancaster and their Beaufort cousins, and the House of York. The four player game adds in the powerful House of Stafford, and the ever-scheming Richard Neville and his son, Richard of Warwick, the 'Kingmaker'.

Using intuitive mechanics, Crown of Roses offers players a historical feeling with tremendous strategic depth and excellent replayability. Unit starting locations vary with each turn and even with each game, and the use of blocks creates the "fog of war" of limited intelligence on enemy strength and deployment. Random game events throw a touch of the chaos of the era into the mix, and the multiple uses for the player action cards leads to a level of uncertainty where enemy plans are concerned.

During each game turn in Crown of Roses, players will play cards to perform actions such as improving their armies, influencing the locals to support them, collecting supplies or prestige, moving to attack enemy forces, to recruit new houses to your cause, calling another Royal Heir into the fray, or even changing the nature of the conflict through the use of player events.

Unit blocks rotate to show strength, and each army can have a variety of experience levels and combat capabilities. A novel roll to hit-based system is used to determine combat results, with better experienced forces scoring hits more often in battle. Kill all of the enemy heirs, and you can rule England unimpeded!

In Parliament, players can try to gain a favorable posting or take control of the crown itself by gathering enough noble support. Gather enough votes for enough years and the nobles of parliament will welcome you as their sovereign!

And if you can create enough influence with the local gentry, your economic might will sway the common folk to support you as their chosen monarch!

And the four player game of Crown of Roses allows all of this and more without the sacrifice of the unique fog of war aspect that the unit blocks provide. With each player having up to three ways to win, who knows who will be the next King of England!"

TIME SCALE Variable

MAP SCALE Area Movement

UNIT SCALE Noble houses and mercenary factions

NUMBER OF PLAYERS Two to Four

COMPONENTS:
22x24 inch Cardboard Game Map
54 Large Wood Blocks
27 Small Wood Blocks
222 Counters
1 sheet of 54 Block Stickers
15 6-sided Dice
110 playing Cards
2 Color Play Aid Cards
8 Parliament/Office Cards
4 Player Mats
1 Rules book
1 Scenario and playbook

DEVELOPERS: Andy Young and Kevin Bernatz
ART DIRECTOR/PACKAGING: Rodger B. MacGowan
MAP ART: Knut Grünitz
CARD & COUNTER ART: Charles Kibler
36480.name: Crown of Roses

36481.description: Winsome Games' latest Age of Steam expansion will be part of the 2008 Essen Set. Set in the Wild West, this expansion introduces two new Actions: Ranching and Cattle Drive. It includes 32 Cattle cubes. Moooooo!
36481.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Texas, Oklahoma & New Mexico

33185.name: Wings of War: Eagles of the Reich Squadron Pack

36482.description:
The WW2 series of Wings of War is an easy, fun to play, fast and furious system which previous fans of the game will be able to start playing minutes after opening the box! New game mechanics support a simulation which must encompass planes with very different flight capabilities and firepower, while still keeping the flow of the combat simple as it is in the WW1 series. The innovations to maneuver cards and to the fire deck system provide all the needed historical accuracy with no headaches to the players!

“Fire from the Sky” is the second set in the new series of Wings of War games, which will allow you to re-create dogfights, bombing missions, escorts, and endless other aerial combat situations set in World War Two. New fighters are introduced into the system, among which the Curtiss P-40 Tomahawk featured in several allied color schemes including the famed Flying Tigers. Airacobra, Yak 1, Reggiane Re.2001 Falco II, Hien and several other fighters from every WWII front are also included. The newest add to the system are Anti-Aircraft guns in ground nests and three different dive bombers: Stuka for the Axis, Val for Japan and Dauntless for United States and France.
Up to 6 planes can fly with the contents of this set, for scenarios with 1 to 6 players.

Part of the Wings of War series

Expanded By:

Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II
Wings of War: Flying Legend Squadron Pack
Wings of War: Eagles of the Reich Squadron Pack
36482.name: Wings of War: Fire from the Sky

boardgameaccessory.39333: Wings of War: WW2 Airplane Packs

boardgamefamily.55: Wings of Glory / Wings of War

36483.name: All Aboard
36483.description:
From the box: "An educational and fun trivia-type game of railroad facts, history & modeling."

The six knowledge categories on each card are: People and Times, Engineering, Hobos and Slanguage, Railroadiana, Model Railroading and Caboose[appears to be general train knowledge].

Default game is to nine correct answers but the rules mention you can set the endgame to any number you like.

The cards are color coded so they can be used with other trivia-type games [example: you could replace the Trivial Pursuit deck with this deck].

The questions are not easy.

36484.name: SnowCrystals Game
36484.description:
SnowCrystals is a beautiful and challenging pattern game. The game contains 96 diamond shaped tiles with segments from five different snow crystals printed on them. The goal of the game is combine and match the pieces to form completed snow crystals. SnowCrystals is appealing to adults as well as Ages 5 and up.

The snow crystal designs were patterned after the photographs of snowflakes in the historic book SnowCrystals by W.A. Bentley and W.J. Humphreys, Dover Publications - New York, 1962.

36485.name: Raleigh Burner BMX Game
36485.description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to get his BMX bike completely over the FINISH line, having got there by luck and skill in the use of Race Cards and dice.
The game board is enhance by "dirt" ramps (jumps and berms), and the playing pieces are actual little BMX bikes.

36486.description:
Army of Ireland is a tactical level recreation of the historically significant Battle of Ridgeway, where encroaching Fenians clashed with spirited Canadian militia in what is now Ontario.

From the publisher:

In the period immediately following the American Civil War, a group of Irish-Americans known as the Fenians conceived of a bold plan that they hoped would result in freedom for Ireland. A volunteer army, comprised mainly of hardened Civil War veterans, was established for the purpose of an invasion of Canada. The Fenians reasoned that territory seized from British controlled Canada could be bartered for Irish independence. Army of Ireland is a tactical level recreation of the historically significant Battle of Ridgeway, where encroaching Fenians clashed with spirited Canadian militia in what is now Ontario. Colorful counters, a detailed hexmap, and other components provide everything needed to re-fight this conflict which was to have a profound influence on Canadian history.
36486.name: Army of Ireland

36487.name: Burmese Monopoly
36487.description:
This is a very primitive copy of Monopoly from Burma (Myanmar).
It was purchased at a Burmese market in about 1990. As in all monopoly sets, the streets are named differently, but the play is the same. In Burmese Monopoly, all of the streets are named after cities and towns in the country of Burma.

36488.name: Heart Patient
36488.description:
"Each player takes the role of a Heart Patient. Object: Be the patient to live the longest."

The game uses a custom deck of cards consisting of six types: Medical Interventions, Lifestyle Modifications, Surgery, Pathological Events, Drug Therapies, and Heart Attack Cards.

Each player rolls up a character/patient to establish seventeen "risk factors", which include items such as Family History, Cholesterol Levels (LDL, HDL, and Total), Weight, Diabetes, Alcohol, and Smoking.

36489.name: Heavy Metal Mayhem
36489.description:
A card game which takes its theme from the universe of the science-fiction film Heavy Metal.

The game uses a custom deck of cards. There are five types of cards in the deck: Hero (Heroine), Foe, Location, Travel, and Special Cards.

The first player to make five melds wins the game. A meld consists of one Hero/Heroine card, two Foe cards, two Location cards, a Travel card, and a Special card.

36490.name: High Seas Fleet
36490.description:
"Simple World War I Naval Combat rules. Map, counters, and dice game." Played on a hex map showing sea and land hexes.

Scale: The rules specify that each hex is 600 feet across (one Nautical mile = 10 hexes), each round is one minute, and each counter is one ship.

The players alternate moving one ship at a time. The players may have any of their ships fire some or all of their guns at any time. A gun battery can only be fired once per turn. When all ships have moved once, the round ends.

Statistics, including unit costs, are included for over twenty ships and submarines of the British and German fleets, as well as for shore batteries and mine fields. The rules cover factors such as anti-submarine warfare, aircraft, aircraft carriers, hidden u-boat movement, and torpedoes.

36491.name: Ice Lords
36491.description:
"Wargame for 2 or more players. Fantasy Northern theme. Victory: Destroy all enemy units."

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. Map tiles are randomly distributed in the center 49 squares, the border squares being considered sea spaces. The terrain tiles come in eight different types: tundra, glacier, water, villages, forest, mountains, peaks, and hills.

Each player starts with one Hero unit placed on a Village tile. The players must recruit units and build armies. Units that may be recruited include Norsemen, Barbarians, Viking Ships, Northern Dwarves, White Dragons, Frost Giants, Polar Bears, Ice Witches, and Yetis. A deck of Spell Cards is used to determine the capabilities of units that have magical powers. Players can augment their forces with relics (Magic Axe, Druid's Staff, or Banner) which increase the power of certain units.

36492.name: Interzone
36492.description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Based on the novel 'Naked Lunch' by William S. Burroughs. Each player is a 'junkie writer' living in the Interzone. The Interzone is a fantasy underworld city of addiction, intrigue, drugs, monsters, homosexuality, hedonism, control, humor, despair, and violence. Writers compete to be the first to finish their book."

"Game play: Writers convert Junk (drug) cards into pages (of their book). Writers make contacts (Junkies, Doctors, Monsters, etc) that they can use to attack (& defend themselves from) their opponents."

"Victory: The first player to write 213 (or more) pages wins."

36493.name: Jaws
36493.description:
"Card Game for 2 players. One player gets the Shark Deck. The other player gets the Shark Hunter Deck. The Hunters have a fishing boat. The boat has 5 Hull points. There are 5 people in the boat. The shark has 10 life points."

"Winning: A game of survival - if all five people are eaten, the Shark player wins. If the Shark is reduced to zero life points the Hunter player wins."

36494.name: Knaves & Knights
36494.description:
Abstract fantasy warfare game. The object is to destroy, capture, or control all of your opponent's pieces.

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. Each player has a set of sixteen pieces, two each of eight types: Knave, Beauty, Royalty, Knight, Sorcerer, Monster, Army, and Castle.

A six-sided die is rolled to determine movement points. These points can be split among one or more units, with each a movement point being expended for each square entered. Cards are used to make attacks. Each card may only be used by one type of unit.

36495.name: Hack & Slash
36495.description:
"You are a Barbarian Warrior surrounded by enemies. Kill them all before they kill you. Solo card game."

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are three kinds of cards in the deck - Attacker, Defense, and Kill Cards. Each turn the player chooses to draw one to three cards. Defense and Kill cards are kept in the player's hand (up to a maximum of six), and Attacker cards are placed face up on the table. Each Attacker in play at the end of the turn causes one point of damage to the player (up to a maximum of four points per turn).

"You have 10 hit points. If you are reduced to zero Hit points you lose."

"If you go through the whole deck without dying you win (You have escaped). Your score is equal to the number of hits you have left plus the number of attackers you killed."

36496.name: Rome Is Burning
36496.description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Roman Emperor theme. Players compete for the chance to be Emperor. The most Decadent player wins."

"Each player is either the Emperor or a Plebeian. Only one player at a time can be the Emperor At the beginning of the game all players start out as Plebeian."

The game uses a custom card deck containing numerous subdivided classes of cards, the two main categories being Assassinations and Bread & Circuses. Other cards types include Political Support, Military Support, Intrigue, Soldiers, Reputation, Private Entertainments, Public Entertainments, Orgies, Tortures, Arena Games, and Decrees.

The game board is a circular track divided into twelve spaces. Two cards are placed on each space and the players collect cards as they move around the track. The players score points based on the cards they hold, certain cards scoring points for Plebians and other cards scoring points for the Emperor.

"Victory: The player with the highest Score at the end of 7 turns wins."

36497.name: Knights Templar
36497.description:
"Card game for 2-4 players. Each player is a faction of the Knights Templar. Players try to build the best Legacy for the Templars possible. The game ends when one player has 5 or more Downfall cards, or when there are no more cards in the deck."

The game uses a custom deck composed of nine types of cards: Legacy, Allies, County, Treasures, Mission, Power, Battles, Enemies, and Downfall. Collecting certain types of cards provides Victory Points. The winner is the player with the most Victory Points at the end of the game.

36498.name: Krull Quest
36498.description:
"Board & Dice game for 2 players. Based on the Fantasy Film Krull. One player is the Good Prince Colwyn. The other player is the Evil Beast in his teleporting Black Fortress."

The game is played on a circular track divided into thirty-two spaces. Every fourth square is a Village. Each player has one pawn. The Colwyn player's pawn represents Prince Colwyn and his Companions, numbering ten men at start. The Beast player's pawn represents the Beast in the Black Fortress.

The Beast wins by razing all eight Villages or by killing the Prince. The Prince wins by locating the Black Fortress, killing the Beast, and saving Princess Lyssa.

36499.name: Lawrence of Arabia
36499.description:
"Card Game for 2+ players. Each player represents an incarnation of Lawrence of Arabia. Players recruit Arab allies and use them to attack the Turks. Victory: The first player to have Mission cards in his Victory pile with a total Force Rating of 40 or more wins."

The game uses a custom deck of cards. There are five types of cards in the deck: Events, Leaders, Tribesmen, Missions, Defenses. The players put Leader cards into play in order to recruit Tribesmen. Leaders and Tribesmen are assigned to complete missions on Mission Cards. Defense cards are played against other players. Each time a Leader and his band are used for a mission, there is a chance they may disband and be removed from the player's control after the mission has been completed.

36500.name: Lunar Conquest
36500.description:
"Sci-Fi Themed Card game. Lunar Warfare between 3 main Factions."

"The Lunarians live underground and were not even aware of the Humans presence. Likewise the Humans did not know about the Lunarians. When the Silexians arrived, in a single colony ship, they immediately detected and Proceeded to Attack the colonies of both other races. All sides have been openly hostile to each other in the ensuing confusion & carnage."

The Lunarians start with six Bases each having a Force value of six, the Humans with four Bases each having a Force value of four, and the Silexians with two Bases each having a Force value of five. Each player uses a unique deck of Unit, Event, and Modifier cards which are used to launch attacks and to defend Bases.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the enemy Bases.
